112153393.review:
Some notions first: 
System Shock is an early try on 3D FPS shooting, released on 23.09.1994, which surprisingly nailed many things of the genre, given that there were not many such games before it. It has full 3D graphics with similar movement controls to WASD, but this original version didn't use mouse to move the camera; instead your mouse is a basic cursor which you use to point objects to interact with or point enemies to shoot them. For many not highly enthusiastic gamers, the controls are an immediate turn off I assure, but they are in fact very integral part of the game once you get used to them, since the game is not meant to be played in a very hectic manner that more modern controls would enable. 
To move the camera around, you use keyboard buttons or certain mouse commands, but the former method is much more fluent way to play if you take the time to learn it. The modernized ’Enhanced Edition’ of this game is the easiest way to experience this game, but it takes away a certain appeal that the clunkier controls force you in, since when you cannot turn around super fast, you really need to use all the options on your neural interface to help you out. Of course, the enhanced version can be played with the original controls too and I totally recommend to play that version with them, but I had some technical issues with that I didn't have with the emulated version via DosBox, so I had to play the last-mentioned.

The actual review: 
System Shock is a brilliant shooter exploration experience, where an AI called Shodan has taken over a space station, where you are trapped in as well as seemingly one of the very few survivors. Your mission is to prevent the AI from reaching it's ill goals against humanity and shut down it for good. Through voice emails this AI mocks and threatens you along the way, actually being a rather scary and intimidating character. It can do this because you wear "a military grade neural implant" on you, which is a rare piece of equipment for combat and other demanding tasks, with slots to add in new tools as you find them by exploring. This is the game's way to upgrade your character, by steadily introducing you new tools and upgrades for them, to fight back cyborgs of the space station and to simply survive by avoiding their surprise attacks and enduring their fire power. The tough thing about this suite is that it requires energy when you activate it’s tools, like for example energy shield that absorbs damage. Battery of the suite will be drained when any power requiring tool is on, which means you need to refill it constantly by finding energy sources on the huge station. On top of that of course, you also have your health to worry about.

The station is huge with total of ten levels you travel between via elevators. You can always go back to an earlier level if you missed something or need to do something next there, since the game doesn't progress strictly in a linear fashion, but instead makes you move around the station and between the levels to accomplish various tasks to ruin Shodan's horrific plans. All the levels are rather maze like, but I think this very corridor and corner heavy design of the game works perfectly here, making you alarm at all times since you never know if there is a deadly cyborg just behind the next corner, even though they do make sounds often. 
The cyborgs are deadly enemies, that you cannot sustain far more than a few seconds if there is two or more them shooting directly at you. Fortunately, you have your suite's tools to help you out, as well as grenades and temporal consumable boosts, like one that slows time. Of course you have various different weapons too, with usually two ammo types; choosing the right ammo type makes an appropriate enemy go down quicker. 
You need to use all your abilities to survive on the station, thinking before engaging, and perhaps most importantly use lean and crouch/prone functions to make yourself as minimally visible as possible to the enemies, so they wouldn't hit you hard. Lean is extremely important in this game, so use it if you suspect there is a danger ahead.

The story of this game is interesting and certainly drives you forward. The audio log system you may have seen in many more modern games is taken straight from this one. Logs and notes tell how the horrible events of Shodan taking control elapsed and they also give you very important information on what to do and where locates what on the station. They can also offer crucial codes.
Shodan is truly a legendary antagonist in gaming history that you certainly don't feel any empathy towards at all - it is in the end an AI of course, even if it's capable of thinking complex stuff. System Shock really offers a worthy purposeful goal for you to achieve as it’s setting, with an enemy that drives you to beat it, which not a great number of games do as successfully.

The brilliance of this game comes from a mix of all these mentioned elements, which together create a tense and even scary experience due to lethal enemies and dark rooms. This game is mostly shooting and exploring yes, but you need to solve various puzzles along the way too and also think your approach in the maze like 3D space, that can basically have an enemy placed anywhere you look; above, below, behind a hidden door, etc. You have to be careful and search carefully for every bit of aid you can find in the station. Yet, the enemies can respawn, which means you cannot run across already cleared places completely care free.
A necessary mention is also cyperspace, that you need to occasionally visit via some terminals you find, but it mostly feels like a simplistic flying game in 3D space, that offers you upgrades and messages that are hidden inside the space away from Shodan to reach, who has control over the whole station's computer network. It is still a neat atmospheric piece of gameplay for sure.

What differentiates System Shock from other not as remarkable shooters, is the forementioned fact how effectively it uses 3D space, but also audio and it's primitive lighting, to create a tense and even scary experience, where at the same time character progression feels natural, where exploration is really rewarding, and where taking a look at your surroundings is important to be able to navigate around and complete tasks (you have a map though). Every aspect of this game feels meaningful, making you think in one way or another, at the same time being constantly interactive and challenging. I would call this game 'a thinking man's shooter'.

If you enjoy FPS games in general, this might work for you if fluent controls are not a must. If those controls are the only issue, then just play the enhanced version. For those who like stories only, this game actually works too, since you can adjust difficulty of the game with four sliders, even toning it down to a bare story run with enemies that don’t attack you. For anybody who wants to fully experience the game though, I recommend the default difficulty settings, since on the hardest difficulties the game really becomes a hard experience, especially if you enable a time limit of seven hours, which is only meant for veterans of this game (I haven’t used it). 
This game can be basically recommended for any keen gamer, especially for those who wonder why somebody would say 90s were the golden age of computer gaming, or if one simply wants to learn about great video game design.

This was my third attempt, over the years, to play System Shock. I replay the sequel every couple of years, it's one of my top ten favorite games, and since this one is so iconic I thought if I tried hard enough I would learn to like it.

And I tried. Like, I really tried.

At risk of beating a dead horse, yes, the controls are as bad as they say. The idea of a two-layered interface-- one using the mouse for conventional aiming and shooting, the other for interacting with your inventory-- is fine, but there are too many files and folders to navigate, too many items to sift through and little feedback as to what does what, what is equipped where, what buttons you should press to do this or that. Since dragging-and-dropping loot is a vague, poorly explained crap-shoot mechanic with little feedback in the game world or user interface as to whether what you just tried to do succeeded or failed, exploration and survival becomes more of a constant hassle as you will be too busy fighting the game to enjoy fighting the monsters.

I've been told the story is good, but since the text in audio logs does not match the actual lines being spoken I can't just set a log to play while I struggle with my inventory because I'm too busy reading the text to make sure I don't miss something. Imagine trying to read a book while someone tells you a separate story in your ear at full volume. That's how the story is delivered to you in game. On top of that, there are emails and text messages that are very easy to miss as they often come bundled with other bits of lore and are stored in your maze of an inventory where you might not know where to look. But you have to do it. You have to do all of it. You need that door code, after all.

And the shooting? It's there, I guess. Monsters spot you, approach you, attack you, like in, say, Wolfenstein 3D, or House of the Dead. You attack them back and hopefully kill them with whatever is in your hand at the time. Afterward, as you catch your breath, you get to look through your inventory and pontificate on what items might have helped you in that last encounter, if you had taken the time to browse, click, browse, click, equip, and use them. Boy, that grenade sure sounds useful. I hope I don't forget I have it later!

I got through a particularly challenging fight-- not "boy, that was exciting" challenging, more "boy, that sure was a test of patience" challenging-- looted corpses, sorted my inventory, refamiliarized myself with the controls for the tenth time and as I rounded a corner the game crashed. I hadn't saved in a while because I wasn't expecting an enhanced version of a game from 1994 to, well, crash. At that point I think the universe was trying to tell me something. 

So, no, I do not recommend this game, much less the original. Just play 2 again instead, it's better in every way and you don't even need mods to run it.

A classic. Groundbreaking in it's time, and it still holds up. The funny part is that nobody since has totally captured all the things System Shock does in one game. There are elements of it all over, from Half Life, to Portal, to the laterr fallouts, to any number of other games in the scifi-horror-fps genre... But nobody quite captures all of the things that System Shock does. Additionally, the virtual reality sections are quite imaginative and original. 

At the core, System Shock is a sci-fi horror game with a great story to tell, set in a space station environment that seems real and lived in. It is an early FPS, and while it originally suffered a bit in contemporary replay, because of wonky early FPS controls, the enhanced version fixes most of that wonkyness. There are still quirky elements of the control interface that have been done better since then, but it is totally playable and enjoyable. It's not a slog at all. In fact, it's a joy. System Shock is an extremely well written game. It is a classic that is good for more than just being a piece of history. It is playable, entertaining, and sometimes even scary. It still works as a game, which is surprising given the tech advances since. It transcends it's limitations. I am confident that even for someone experiencing it for the first time, there is still magic to be found that will charm and delight. This is an old game that is very much worth playing. 

System Shock is to sci-fi and horror games, as H.G. Wells or Jules Verne are to sci-fi books. Just as groundbreaking and worthwhile ever. Timeless, because it speaks to the experience of being human in a fascinating, and sometimes terrifying future.

98911333.review:
How good is this game? Amazing.
Do I recommend it? Yes.
How hard is it to get into it? Pretty hard, but once you mastered the lock and unlock mouse, everything else will start to click.

Locking and unlocking is done by pressing E (default) and doesn't prevent you from doing things outside of turning with the mouse, so you can still shoot stuff if need be. And you can annotate the map. This is all you need to start a run.

Now the real question is how to explain how amazing this game is?

Often, a game require the player to master it to feel good. System Shock, despite some clunkiness, manage to give the feeling you are mastering more and more the game all the while throwing shit hard enough that you have to be on your toes.

It give gadgets that are useful, but sometimes you have to learn them. It gives good guns and ammo types, but again you have to understand them, good grenades, good utility items.

Basically, where most games give you a feeling of being good, System Shock will force you to start to break it to feel it. It make it look like doesn't care how much shit it throws at you, but we are walking that thin edge were you feel amazing about overcoming real odds, no bullshit that simply make the game a walk in the park.

This game is also amazing because of it's ambiance: with keeping the player on their toes, it mix with it a grim situation and manage to keep us under pressure.

The story isn't new or anything, but the writing of SHODAN, the fact the player isn't railroad'd into actions ("who said we need to raise the shield before firing the laser if I want an early game over?"), also add into this whole feeling you are free to figure out how to beat the game.

Many games tried to sell us a villain that can say "Look at you, hacker. A pathetic creature of meat and bone. Panting and sweating as you run through my corridors. How can you challenge a perfect immortal machine?" and not sound ridiculous. System Shock doesn't try, SHODAN is one hell of a villain.

Yet the game isn't without flaws by modern standards: no quest logs, clunky controls, the sprites sometimes go wild (looking down on an enemy, the sprite will remain perpendicular to the view) to name the biggest, most noticable offenders.

If the looks could be upgraded*, the other parts will, in the end, always be there in a way or another: no quest log is great for ambiance, as you have to take notes on the minimap of stuffs, relistening to audiologs to figure what to do and so on. The clunky controls can't really be fixed as there is just way too many things you can and have to do, the current schemes is pretty amazing by default.

There is, in theory, a remake coming down the road, I hope it works out, this game truly deserve that. And even people that can't get into the old ass interface or graphics should discover that title, even if it's remasterised.

TL;DR: This is fucking amazing buy it. And if graphics and all aren't you thing, try to support to NightDive Studio because they are working on a remastered. It has an amazing atmosphere, it is rewarding, and it's well written.

First things first: the button is in the same room as the isotope. No need to waste hours looking all over 6 floors trying to find an off switch for the forcefield. Don't worry, you'll understand this advise when the time comes. Everything else you need is detailed in the audio logs, so if you're stuck, just go over those again.

Alright, with that out of the way: this game is great. I will go further and say that it makes many first person shooter games that came out both before and after look like bland garbage. It is honestly kind of insane just how amazing this game is considering that it came out shortly after the original Doom and before Doom 2.

Do you like pointless and ineffectual weapons? Random garbage littering the floor? Redundant Night Vision? Pointless audio logs  about people going to the movies? This may all sound like a complaint, but all the inane things they included make this crusty old game feel like a lived in space - you know, before the MURDERS. Exploration never got boring and in spite of the very dated and somewhat stilted voice acting, I was always eager to see what was around the next corner.

What did I find? Usually death in some variant. Mostly severed heads, lot of those in boxes. And soda. Very often I would open a door for a death machine to separate my limbs from my torso. This game loves its ambushes and will respawn enemies *just enough* to keep you on your toes. Sometimes you can walk a level backwards and forwards and never see a single enemy respawn. Sometimes you turn a corner you just cleared and three security bots are waiting to turn you into an ash heap. Caution is the name of the game - this is a sci-fi dungeon crawler and you *will* crawl like the insect you are if you want to survive.

The interface in this game feels more like piloting a flesh mech than a first person shooter, and honestly I kind of love it. All the little button and nobs as you try to arm yourself with various weapons - ranging from totally useless to gamebreakingly absurd. Did I mention you can get a lightsaber in this game and that if used properly it will carry you through most fights? What if I told you you get rocket skates that when paired with a berserk drug and a reflex booster more or less turns you into a particularly frothy Jedi? Just keep in mind that when I say "game breaking" I mean that literally, as you will be tripping out so hard from that combo that you will be practically blind for the next few minutes. 

In a lot of games, grenades tend to be very wimpy - not so in this game. They have a decent blast radius and the stronger ones can nuke you in one go. No in this game the only thing that is weak is your character's throwing arm. The expression "throws like a girl" could be used here, but I feel that is giving him too much credit. The hacker does not throw grenades so much as he gently lofts them from his hands. I would go so far as to say that they merely roll out of his palms and onto the floor followed shortly by his legs flying past his head. A lot of nerdy men get bullied by jocks in highschool - the hacker would have been bullied by the glee club. If you want to use grenades, I suggest you either do so from an elevation, from a prone position (gives you a better throwing arc without hitting the roof), or simply throwing an unarmed grenade and shooting it at a distance. There are more options, but understand that using grenades like you would in other games will get you killed 9 times out of 10

The game also has cyber space sections, these are not very challenging but I enjoy them and their strange flight simulator like controls. BTW: press S to speed up. But you get to pull things like pointless mini-games that you can play on your military grade cyber interface - so that by itself worth while. While I'm rattling off pointless things, the music and sound design is very weird and detailed. Feels like it is always changing based on what I'm doing and where I'm going. Extremely dynamic and it is impressive how much work must have gone into it. Just don't have headphone on if you go into radiation rooms. Your character will get cancer and you'll get tinnitus. 

Now, if you'll excuse me: I have to replay this game on the canon difficulty. Seven hours to save the world from Shodan or be stepped on by cyber mommy.

System Shock 1 is a Classic game made by the legendary Looking Glass Studios and remastered by Nightdive Studios.

The Game came out in 1994 september 23, only shy by a month compared to Doom 2 !

The Graphics 9/10:

The Graphics presented are very much ahead of their time. Compared to Ultima Underworld, Looking Glass's older game with the same Engine, the differences are day and night. Detailed pixelart with an artstyle detailing grotesque mutations and such with complex designs, very much held up nice. The enviroment is also very advanced for the time, with slopes and not just 90 degree walls, with interesting places to explore, such as a medical facility, executive areas, a shuttle bay for ships land, and even Garden Groves infested with Mutagenic plant and animal life.
One thing that bothered me is the scaling effect when looking up or down at an enemy, and yes this was pretty standard at the time, and even advanced because years later games still used this scaling property. Still would've liked a way to disable it and make then visible normally. The cyberspace areas in the game are weird, and weirdly ahead of their time ? Maybe not, it's like a polygon based Descent. It's weird and uncanny but about that later. But yeah for Graphics I'd settle down for a 9, it looks great for its time and looks great even now.

The Music 10/10:

For me, the music is one of the best parts of this game. It's a shame that we won't hear much of the old tunes presented here in the near-coming remake of the game.
So the music is best in Chorium Rev A or in just dos, most midi Devices don't give the soundtrack enough justice.
System shock's soundtrack is very varied and expanding, places such as Med sci and Research have a kinda gloomy but rocking feeling to them, while others such as Maintenance and Flight Decks have some haunting and distrubing tracks to them. Also the games doesn't just stick to one music all the time, when you face  [/spoiler Edward Diego] in Executive sector the soundtrack goes really hard to get you invested in the fight. Best tracks for me personally would go for Reactor, Executive and Security/Bridge. They have this ass kicking vibe to them, but also can go for a slower more methodicaly approach that always changes up how you approach certain places. One game where buying the soundtrack itself isn't a bad acquisition, so that's why it gets a 10 out of 10.

The Ui and Controls 8/10:

Yeah...the most controversial part about the game and why it was more outdated back then compared to now.
Most would describe the game as tank controls, but I think skate roller with vaseline would describe it better.
Yes you get adapted to it, and the inventory system got noticeably better, still this is why people are afraid to try this game out. It gets and 8 out of 10 just becuase of the learning curve and later modification making the controls even weirder and ice-like.

The Gameplay 9-10/10

This is where the games shines or dwindles as to what you like. If you like a deep, dark cyberpunk story with a benevolent crazed Ai with a god complex and Matrilineality, this is the game for you. But if you don't like having to collect keys, pass codes, pass codes from e-mails or [/spoiler HAVING TO GO BACK TO EVERY PART OF THE GAME TO GET ONE WHOLE NUMBER], then I would suggest skipping this one. The Majority of the game let's you explore and feel the place at your leisure, you always have the time to suck all the diabolical things that happended to you collagues. The shooting feels satisfying, the movement is... decent, the story is gripping, the atmosphere is haunting and well designed, dialogues are well...very 90s, also yeah, this was the first game to actually support voice messages or in this case, e-mails, that lots of games to this days like Bioshock use. This game invented so many genre necessities, and was so ahead of it's time that back then, it got panned pretty hard, which will haunt Looking Glass for their next two titles, both of them set so many generalities that to this day stand, that back then they couldn't handle it. Also the difficulty is pretty fair I would say. You can adjust everything in the game. If you don't like the whole code searching key hunting mother cucking things, tone down story and puzzles.
In my opinion gameplay wise this is a hit or miss, but when it hits. it hits very VERY hard.

The S.H.O.D.A.N 15/10
I won't spoil nothing. Just saying that this game got the best Rouge Ai in the existence of fiction... well for me atleast.


So in the end I would give this game a fair and balanced [b 9.5 out of 10]. A Classic video game that set standards so high that it doesn't even feel fair

93190003.review:
Before Bioshock and Deus Ex we had System Shock: still an absolute classic to this very day. It's not Doom so don't expect that going into it but rather you should expect the birth of the immersive sim. A slow paced, difficult, tactical horror FPS and one of the earliest story-focused shooters ever made. It gets SO many things right that most modern shooters fail miserably when it comes to storytelling and world building. And the best part is by far the villain; the one and only Shodan. As usual in my reviews I break things down:

Pros
- Challenging but satisfying tactical combat
- Massive and highly explorable space station with excellent level design
- No hand holding, it's up to you to figure it all out and rewards players who pay attention
- A unique interface and control scheme that sets it apart from other shooters even for its time
- Highly adjustable difficulty settings for individual gameplay elements
- Lots of weapons, ammo types, grenades, upgrades and consumables to allow for many styles of play
- Lots of horror and spooks
- Excellent soundtrack
- Great art style with some gorgeous and grotesque enemies and environments for its time
- Amazing storytelling focused on audio logs and environmental scenery
- Shodan is a scary waifu

Cons
- Music can be too loud and energetic for its dark, slow paced horror atmosphere
- Over-reliance on hitscan robot enemies
- Movement mechanics are bizarre, sometimes getting launched or slowed down for no reason
- Control scheme might be too cumbersome for most players
- Too much ammo, robots and cyborg enemy corpses drown you in it
- Cyberspace sections, while rare, they suck despite being cool and impressive in 1994
- Audio logs spoken dialogue is completely different to the written dialogue they come with
- Voice acting is stilted and dull, except for Shodan
- Sound design is a hilariously loud mess, especially in radiation zones
- While the final parts of the game are great especially the visuals for the final boss, the ending cutscene is very abrupt and disappointing

All that said, my gripes are very minor and are well overshadowed by everything System Shock does so very right. Nightdive's work on bringing this classic up to date for modern systems is nothing short of spectacular and its very cheap price point makes it well worth the buy especially if you're looking for a lengthy game where a first playthrough can last up to 15 hours like mine did. If you're put off by the control scheme or any other aspect of the game then rejoice because the System Shock remake is drawing close at the time of writing this review and I'm so excited to step back onto Citadel Station in all its modernised glory.

It has definitely become one of my favourite games and I recommend this janky masterpiece wholeheartedly.

Of course, the enemies' AI is poor or lacking at all. There is not enough space in the inventory to use all the guns you find. And the movement is still not that fluent we are used to be in modern games, especially in some narrow and diagonal corridors.

I had previously played, and quite enjoyed, System Shock 2 (SS2) in previous years but had some serious issues in getting invested in SS:EE. The clunky controls and dated visuals, not to mention the learning curve and initial difficulty level, really turned me off and left a bad taste in my mouth. I found myself installing and uninstalling several times over a period of a few months. 

With the recent announcement of the System Shock remake coming later in 2021, I figured it was high time to sit down and give System Shock: Enhanced Edition (SS:EE) another try. I knew that I was going to be picking up the remake and in a way I felt I owed it to myself to play the grandfather of SS2. I had sunk a lot of hours into SS2 and my enjoyment had pushed me to try its spiritual successor, Bioshock, which I also thoroughly enjoyed. With that said, I booted it up, played for 30 minutes, and was promptly murdered.

Rather than uninstall it, I did some digging on the internet to figure out what I was doing wrong and came across several helpful guides regarding something I hadn’t realized was such a linchpin in my experience: the controls. Oh, gods, the controls. Once I made some adjustments to the controls following some helpful suggestions and adapting a couple things to my specific keyboard, SS:EE opened up to me. 

If you’ve ever played Doom 1993, Hexen, Duke Nukem 3D, or Blake Stone and found them enjoyable you have to do yourself a favour and try SS:EE. It has the right amount of cyberpunk flavouring to stand it apart from other shooters, the weapons are varied and feel suitably unique, the various ammunition and damage types don’t just make it a “grab the biggest gun and you auto win,” and the enemies are challenging enough that you’ll find yourself reloading a save more than once.

The puzzles, story, objectives, and level design put the other classics released around its time to shame. This, combined with the enhanced editions voice acting (some of it is hit and miss but keep in mind these are the game devs and some of their friends) really brings you in to the setting. While you never actually meet any of the characters in the game, I will admit that at times I could get into the game enough to feel their sense of dread, anger, or hopelessness. SHODAN is a great antagonist and her voice acting really makes her feelings of loathing and general dismissiveness towards you feel tangible.

I’m not going to get up on a soapbox and tell you SS:EE is a “must play,” but if you were ever a fan of the aforementioned classics I think you owe it to yourself to not only play it but actually give it a chance. While I stumbled hard at the beginning, once I had adjusted the controls to a more modern equivalent, it really came together for me. Such a small thing made such a huge difference. In my humble opinion this game holds up just as well in 2021 as it did back in 1994 and I had a great time playing it and finally finishing it.

86899490.review:
After having completed System Shock 2 for the first time back in 2012 I tried System Shock 1 for the first time in 2017. I played for a bit but abandoned it quite early on. However I do remember some areas and doing one or two cyberspace instances. 

With new determination I restarted the game late 2020 and this time with the inclination to finish it. I watched an introduction video by Mandalore Gaming to get me going, it helps as he explains the interface. I also used a non-spoilery and non-extensive walkthrough that you can find here on Steam to keep track of my missions. There is no quest-log in the game and I didn’t keep my own notes so I thought it was reasonable to keep track of my “quests” by taking a peak at that WT.

This time around I got hooked early on, already on the first level, and it didn’t take long before I became comfortable with the clunky interface. The interface is probably the biggest turn-off for most people and the reason why System Shock isn’t widely played. It's a question of accessibility. But it isn’t as complicated as it appears and you shouldn’t let it discourage you. You can switch between your regular shooter style gameplay, with the crosshair in the middle, to a free mouse cursor mode that allows you to poke around in your inventory and other devices. It actually works quite similar to modern games where you press a key, usually TAB, but in SS1 it’s E, to bring up your Data Reader which is like the PIPBOY in Fallout. 

In System Shock 1 the game doesn’t pause while you are in your inventory so if you are attacked you must quickly shift back again. However you can still fire your gun whilst browsing the interface, the problem is if the enemy is behind you and you need to turn around. But it’s isn’t that big of a problem and you become used to it in no time.

I’m amazed at how many features this old gem from 94’ actually has. First of all there are different stances. You can stand, crouch and crawl. You can lean to the sides and also jump of course. There’s a fatigue meter and you can become exhausted. You have HP and energy. Energy can be drained by energy weapons as well as by your equipment. You have the flashlight of course and you can also get infravision, target tracking and more. There are loads of weapons. Melee weapons, pistols, rifles, energy weapons and more. Most guns can be loaded with different ammo types which makes the arsenal even more versatile. There are also many different types of grenades as well as chems that can alter your physical state. For example the Berserk chem which improves your melee combat for a short duration of time. 

You also have the already mentioned Data Reader in which you collect audio logs, receive emails and other data. And if all this wasn’t enough there are data jacks from where you can enter cyberspace. Cyberspace doesn’t have that huge of a role as I initially thought and there are even levels without data jacks. In cyberspace you can collect stuff, kill programs and unlock doors. You can also gather useful intel. On some levels for example you have to enter cyberspace to be able to pass certain doors in the flesh world. The layout of cyberspace can be confusing at times but you will soon learn to navigate. 

There are also minigames for opening certain doors. The minigames can be bypassed by a disposable item though. You move through the stations levels and you can travel between levels using lifts. For some quests you have to travel back and forth between levels. There’s a lot of different containers and bodies lying around that can be looted for items. Enemies leave lootable corpses.

Each level comes with it's own music (sort of) and it often sets the tone perfectly. 

Few games since have been able to match this extensive mass of features and gameplay systems. System Shock 2 is good but it doesn’t have cyberspace for instance. Then there’s Deus Ex and also Prey from 2017 which came close.

You are the Hacker and have been brought aboard the citadel space station. When you wake up from cryosleep it turns out that everything on the station has gone to hell. The rogue AI Shodan is killing all of the remaining crew members who are by now in an active rebellion but getting decimated fast. The ones who get captured are either turned to mutants or converted into cyborgs. 

The enemies you meet are different types of mutants and cyborgs that Shodan throws at you. Unlike System Shock 2 this isn’t a scary game. In SS2 you sneak around hitting enemies at the back of their heads with the wrench. At some times the ammo scarcity leaves you no other choice. However in SS1 you fight the enemy head on and can kill them quite easily. Ammo isn’t scarce as in SS2 so that gives you no problems. SS2 had a much scarier atmosphere and I even remember screaming out loud at some times when I got ambushed. SS1 in contrast has yet to frighten me. However there are a few surprise ambushes where the walls open and hidden enemies attack you but it never gives you that creeping feel of dread as in other games.

Since I played System Shock 2 before System Shock 1 I already knew the story. However it’s still nicely told through audio logs. You learn of what went wrong and how the desperate crew tried to stop Shodan. However since they failed it’s up to you, the Hacker, to stop Shodan's plans. Each time you prevent Shodan she comes up with another plan but when you’ve stopped her the third time she’s defeated (until SS2). I won’t spoil the story here but it’s your typical rogue AI with illusions of grandeur. Still, Shodan is Shodan, so it feels special. However the ending felt very anticlimatic. I thought it would be much more of a boss fight.

As a completionist and since it was my first tour on Citadel Space Station it took me 21.6 hours to complete according to steam.

A sad thing is that you can see by the achievements that very few people who own the game have actually played it. Only 4% of players have completed the game as of now. There's also an achievment that you can achive in the absolute begining of the game that only 14% of players have achieved. The low number of actual players is sad because this is such a good game. You shouldn't let the interface or the graphics discourage you. It's easy to get used to the gameplay and the game itself is something of a masterpiece. It was so ahead of it's time or was it maybe the pinnacle of it's time? 

I'm very glad that I played this version before the remaster arrives in stores.

80702903.review:
Bad? No. Grossly outdated? Absolutely.

Before writing this review, I had found and read an old gaming magazine article about System Shock. I wanted to open a window to the past and take a look at how it was perceived in its prime. It appears that the game was considered highly innovative. It was praised for being immersive, graphically advanced, featuring complex environment geometry, and having extensive freedom of movement (the article even speculated that "System Shock 2" will feature a "scatch your arse" option to complete the full range of real-life motions). The game was so technically advanced that the author recommended getting a high-end PC to run it smoothly. It's fair to say System Shock pushed many conventional boundaries, consequently influencing the gaming industry in many ways.

Back to the future. It would be senseless to approach SS1 with modern standards. Even with "Enhanced Edition," which upscales resolution and allows for a more streamlined control scheme, a major discount has to be applied to expectations. Some adapt easily to dated graphics and game design; others struggle. As one may have guessed, in this case, I am from the latter category. Allow me to excuse myself.

I was aware of the unwieldy controls. I've played "Enhanced Edition" and spent some time configuring it to suit my comfort. In the end, I had no problems navigating through the game. I knew what to expect from the 1994 graphics. I accepted them as a style and quickly got used to them. I understood that I should not anticipate a complex story from the game, which came out in the era where having a story in a video game was under discussion. The concept is cool; it provides an excuse to shoot space cyborgs, so that's alright. However, I was neither warned nor prepared for one major flaw: outdated level design.

System Shock Citadel is a maze. This statement is not a literary exaggeration, but a fact. I don't need to be reminded about the technical limitations of the time, and I do not blame the game. Nevertheless, as soon as I realized that the whole game is set in a network of claustrophobic labyrinths, negativity started to slowly accumulate until it finally reached irritation. Most of the time in SS1 is spent walking around narrow corridors, stumbling upon locked doors, and painfully backtracking. Everything looks the same and becomes a blurry mess after walking around corners for hours. It takes considerable effort to memorize locations. It literally gave me a headache; my brain was very strained. Sometimes I had to open the map after every turn to make sure I was walking in the right direction. This maze design slowed everything down to a snail's pace. Needless to say, the whole layout didn't make any sense. A space station without a single toilet? Dead ends and hidden doors? Switches that activate something far away? The list can go on, but these are nitpicks. Having said that, there are nitpicks that I considered due to my annoyance with level design.

My tolerance for other outmoded things decreased as a result of my constant irritation. It annoyed me that sometimes it was unavoidable to receive damage from hit-scan enemies. It annoyed me that everything looked like a pixelated mess. It annoyed me that "cyber space" was not just labyrinths, but labyrinths with transparent walls. I was annoyed to have to backtrack through the same locations over and over again. My "list of annoyances" is extensive.

Nonetheless, I finished the game twice. First on normal settings, then on the hardest difficulties (beating Shodan in under 7 hours). Although I did mention a lot of things that irritated me, it would be unfair to classify System Shock as "bad." It's not; it has a lot to offer.

It was "System Shock's" approach to objectives that captivated me till the end. The game does not hold your hand, instead providing clues as to what you are supposed to do. I had to read mails, listen to audiologs, and explore every corner to deduce what to do and how to achieve it. I used a walkthrough a couple of times, but only to clarify some confusions (for example, to learn how to plant a bomb or to find a detail I missed in a sequence of tasks). I can clearly see how "System Shock" could have been immersive for me if I didn't mind the level design so much. Even though backtracking was painful, exploring new areas and discovering secrets was exciting. Even though most enemies were hit-scan marksmen, each had to be approached with appropriate gear. Even though Shodan could have been replaced with a mad scientist without changing the plot, defeating her was exhilarating. Just like with the "list of annoyances," I can list many positive things. Unfortunately, not quite as many.


To summarize, System Shock is a grossly outdated game, albeit not a bad one. I do not recommend playing it to anyone except those who wish to understand how far modern games have evolved. It allows us to appreciate what we have. If you have thick skin when it comes to claustrophobic mazes with narrow tunnels, you may even avoid the irritation that I felt.

A part of me wishes I was able to experience System Shock under different circumstances. Perhaps, when I did not know better and could look at the game with the same eyes as people from 1994. For better or worse, I am not excited about "being able to climb ladders" and "seeing slopes in video games' geometry." For me, these are normal occurrences. Along with many other things that are invisible to my consciousness and that I take for granted. I've heard better stories and seen prettier things. I have experienced numerous games. Progress marches relentlessly forward, dragging us along with it. The fact that "System Shock" is a great game remains, but the reasoning changes. In 1994, it was due to its qualities. Nowadays, due to its legacy.

Synopsis: You're a hacker who has been caught red-handed by TriOptimum. You've been apprehended and brought aboard the "Citadel", a space station. You've been offered military grade cybernetic upgrades in exchange for unleashing an A.I. which eventually evolves into a malicious entity called SHODAN. You peacefully sleep post cybernetic surgery during a 6 month duration while SHODAN overthrows the Citadel crew. You wake up to a ship overrun with cyborgs, mutants, machines, and monsters. Oh my! Worst of all, SHODAN wants to blast a laser at Earth! You have roughly seven hours to thwart SHODAN's schemes before it's too late. Can you do it, Hacker? Hack your way through this to find out!

Basic Controls
WASD = Locomotion
ZC = Lean Left/Right
RFV = Stand/Crouch/Prone
E = Cursor/Aim Mode
Left Click = Grab/Interact
Right Click = Attack
Q = Switch Weapons
Scroller = Switch Weapons

Mechanics
Grab items by double clicking the left mouse button while cursor is over item. Three windows along the bottom of the screen allow you to view a Mini Map, Reload Weapons (Left or Right Window), and peruse Data (Emails, Logs, Data). If you need to view Data, left click E located on the right side of the screen. Various cybernetic upgrades can be activated by clicking on their icons located on the left or right side of the screen.

Hints/Help
In a nutshell, you need to destroy cameras and nodes to weaken SHODAN on every floor of the Citadel. Explore many nooks and crannies to find powerful weapons. Search the bodies of your enemies for ammunition or healing items such as Med. Remember, a dart will not harm a giant robot later in the game unless your combat difficulty is set very low. Lastly, after destroying nodes (those big tall red and black things), write down the number on the small monitor screen (trust me, you'll need it).

System Shock is an atmospheric shooter with light adventure elements. Without spoiling anything, you are a hacker trying to overcome Shodan’s plans, the enemy AI who has taken control of the space station Citadel. System Shock may be the first FPS which tried to blend in story elements with shooter mechanics and it is hard to ignore its importance in the evolution of FPSs, considering it came out 4 years before the original Half-Life.

Whereas System Shock still holds up in some areas (story, atmosphere), it shows its age in others… Shooting is pretty bad and the AI is quite poor. Throughout the game, I have killed many enemies, because they were stuck in a doorway, unable to find their way towards me. The UI is very different from today’s standardized UIs and often criticized, but I honestly enjoyed its sophistication. My main problem with System Shock was the maze-like level design and backtracking. I often found myself trying to figure out how to progress, finding out later that I am supposed go back to a small room five levels (floors) earlier. Hacking mini-games are alright and the inventory management is fun.

Overall, System Shock was too ambitious for its technical limitations in 1994. It definitely deserves respect for what it was trying to do, but if I had to name one game that desperately needs a remake it would be the original System Shock. Thanks to Nightdive Studios, I guess we will get our hands on that out soon…

After an hour of adjusting my keybindings and getting used to the setup I was killing SHODAN's minions on Citadel Station left and right, managing my inventory and equipment without problems, something that I could never achieve in the classic version. The mouse free look alone makes this so smooth and fun to play, even if that feature makes some equipment useless like the "Sensaround Multi-View Unit" that was designed with the old, clunky controls in mind where 360° no-scope turnarounds were simply impossible.
The game runs flawlessly and the controls can be bound to your liking to give it a modern feel (e.g. Q and E to lean, CTRL and ALT to crouch and prone, TAB to switch between free mouse look and GUI mouse movement and much more).
Only one time the game crashed, and that was when I tried to delete an old map note that had its name removed after coming back to a previous level (this bug was supposed to be fixed in the Source Port Update #4 but apparently it's not).
Story wise it's pretty simple and a typical [i]"The Evil AI"[/i] plot, but that AI being SHODAN, with her insulting and demeaning personality and attitude towards human life, is definitely a great highlight that will make you look forward to every communication from her.
The ending was a bit of a letdown though, it just ended too suddenly and the game also got pretty confusing at times where you don't know what to do next, so have a walkthrough or guide ready just in case.

72842141.review:
[h1] Enhanced Edition Review[/h1] 
System Shock was one of the very first games I tried to get running in Dos Box as a young teenager. Not because I was interested in the game itself but heard a lot of praise for the second game so I went out my way and wanted to play this one first. While being somewhat completely different than the second it still captures the same cyberpunk art style and oozes this even more with its soundtrack that is made from Synthesizer. But it gets a lot of work trying to get into the game.

[u]Gameplay[/u]
It looks first like some simple early 90s first person shooter but is far away from that. If you have ever played ghost recon, the game feels like a mix between this and general survival horror game aspects. Also it offers a heavy convoluted HUD which doesn’t only serve as something that takes away more than half of your screen but features most of the unique stuff System Shock is known for. 

Your Hud is basically your cybernetical dashboard offering you Item descriptions, General Information for everything but also as a Tool to convey your various tools you get. As an example, one of the first items you can find is basically a back camera that shows in a very low FPS what’s going on behind you. This doesn’t mean it’s a fantastic designed masterpiece, far from it a lot of the games system can be convoluted without serving much purpose, as an example I found almost no use for the back camera as energy is better used differently.

It’s also somewhat of a stretch between being very Action oriented and trying to be somewhat scary or at least convey an oppressed feeling to the player. If you die u just don’t reload into a save, you see a short clip where you are being transformed as a mindless Cyborg.

And I must say the survival “horror” aspects in this game work, I enjoy it looking around for hidden treasure or just new Datalogs with stories or information from the personnel of the space station you have found yourself in. Fighting itself is totally doable, less action oriented and more about positioning, usage of correct weapons or tools.

Shooter mechanics wise it plays more like a tactical shooter while not being too hardcore. You will be most of the time try to lean around corners and snipe enemies away, or throw grenades into stronger enemies or groups. Enemies can kill you easily in a couple of hits, you wont be ever tanking more than 5 shots from these guys unless using shields. I really like this aspect making it gunplay wise even better than the second game in my opinion. only buzzkill for me was that enemies will constantly respawn. This means you constantly will deal with thrash mobs over and over again when backtracking.

Speaking of backtracking, you will do this a LOT. It got almost to the point where i was ragequitting because i didnt write down node codes, which made me backtrack to a very specific room in every single level making me just walk for a couple of hours . My critique is that the game never really tells you that you have to write down some random number that appears when destroying enough security/nodes in a room.

The worst enemy for most people are the controls which are rather overambitious. As in, it wants you to be able to control everything, heck you can even use a slider to look up or down slightly or lean in different positions making you able up to 9(!) different ways to have your body positioned. But this makes for a messy control scheme that despite remapping never really feels really good to use.

Due to the Hud that is packed full of different side menus and tools new players can get very easily lost and stop playing the game. The standard control mapping doesn’t help that much either as any normal person would put leaning to q and r.

There is also a cyberspace minigame that is just awful and not really fun. It plays like some sort of shooter like decent, except you cant strafe and its visually also a mess. It does help to change the pacing somewhat but overall I dislike this minigame the most.

Map design wise it can also be later on very complicated and I’ve found myself a couple of times stuck and puzzled what to do next

As side note, incase you dislike puzzles or combat the game offers a huge variety of difficulties, makes you enable to make combat easier to puzzles completely gone.

[u]Story[/u]
While not overly complex, its mostly anyways more important how a story is told. Dialogues are witty and don’t hinder the gameplay at all. Rare to see to have a good told story in an action game like this from that era.

[u]Enhanced Edition [/u]
I’m impressed how the well the Enhanced Edition is made. Not only offers it a lot of good improvements, like being able to move your gun while looking around it also has a lot of visual upgrades ranging from taking the hand drawn MAC pictures to making the game less pixelated and the in-game environment, not the models as they still are pixelated.
In case there are purists out there you can also play the classic dosbox Version. Neat! Can’t ask for more.

Another thing i want to add is the lighting. I dont know if the enhanced edition improves this but i feel the general lighting of this game is for this era just fantastic. Dark areas are lit depending on when you shoot with weapons, or use lamps to a certain degree. 

In contrast to other enhanced editions this one is actually more a remaster, as it is the base game but rebuild completely in a source port. 

[u]Sound[/u]
Probably my favourite and most memorable part about the game is the soundtrack. It just sounds to damn fitting. The tracks are just like your Hud convoluted with a lot of audio feedback, synthesizer fight each other or give great melodies making a lot of very complicated and great sounding tracks that support the gameplay a lot or are eerie off sounding to give creepy vibes.

Voice acting of a couple characters is pretty good, but overall i feel a lot of people talk way too monotone despite being in a very life threatening situation.

[u]Conclusion/TL;DR[/u]
While being a game with a very frustrating entry and some annoying gameplay choices like the cyberspace or convoluted controls and Hud I think it’s still worth a game to look into from a modern standpoint because the atmosphere and soundtrack is top notch. If you like survival horror-esque games where its less about the action and more about preparation and the whole exploring around the combat this game is definitely for you.

On a side note they give you the option to play the various old versions, from floppy to cd version you can choose which one you want incase you dont want to play the enhanced version.

[i]'This is Edward Diego from TriOptimum. The charges against you are severe but they could be dismissed if you perform a “service”. Who knows, there might even be a military grade neural interface in it for you... if you do the job right.'[/i]

The year is 2072. You are a hacker caught breaking into the TriOptimum Corporation's computer systems and whisked away to their space station, Citadel. A shady executive, Edward Diego, makes you an offer you can't refuse. Help him hack into the station's AI and remove its ethical constraints and he'll not only wipe your record clean but also give you a state-of-the-art neural interface. This is an opportunity you just can't pass up so you do the deed and receive your reward. When you wake up from your 6 month long healing coma you find that things on the station are not quite as they were before you had your operation...

[i]System Shock: Enhanced Edition[/i] is the legendary immersive sim from Looking Glass Technologies with some added quality of life improvements to help it run better on a modern PC and control in a slightly more user-friendly way. It adds support for higher resolutions and modernises the controls with the addition of mouselook. Aside from this, it's the same game from 1994 and you can even customise the controls to match the original release if you so wish.

Although I have played and finished [i]System Shock 2[/i] I had never previously gone more than a few rooms into the original. I was playing in DOSbox and was struggling with the clunky controls. I just couldn't get into it. Even coming into this version of the game I didn't expect to get very far, but after my first evening of playing the game I found myself pleasantly surprised. I had made the assumption that because this game was older than [i]System Shock 2[/i] that it would be more complex. I would actually argue that this entry in the series is far simpler to grasp. There are no character classes or skills that dictate what equipment you can or can't use. There are no levelling trees at all in fact. You are simply the hacker. You do gain new abilities throughout the game via upgrades to your neural interface but you just pick them up off the floor for the most part. 

The UI is probably the most difficult thing to get your head around and you'd better get used to it quickly. [i]System Shock[/i] just drops you straight into the thick of things. You wake up in the medical bay and by the next room you're swinging a pipe at hostile robot. It wastes no time in giving you your first objective: shutting off the mining laser that's pointing at Earth. You're given some guidance in how to complete your goals but you're not led by the nose. You find information through audio logs and notes scattered around the station. Some of it is relevant to your current objective, some of it might relate to obstacles you're yet to tackle. There were times when I felt like things got a bit muddled because the game gives you free access to the entire station and you can pick up snippets of information you don't need yet. I didn't get too sidetracked though; the critical path through the game is fairly clear if you don't rush things.

If you do find yourself lost, this version of the game comes with some extras in the local files. As well as the original manual you also get the official strategy guide, the [i]I.C.E. Breaker[/i]. This is a really good guide because it's formatted in a way which helps you not spoil yourself on the fine details of the game. At the front you've got a basic checklist of all the main objectives followed by information about enemies and weapons. It's only at the very back that you find puzzle solutions and detailed maps. If you take a break from the game and lose your place, a quick glance at the front of the book will put you back on track.

The combat in [i]System Shock[/i] is straightforward. It works like a slightly clumsy first person shooter. You have a range of weapons including a pistols, rifles, grenades and energy beams. My favourite is the almighty Laser Rapier which lets me flail at SHODAN's minions like a windmill, felling all in my path. This particular weapon is clearly the inspiration for the equally overpowered Dragon's Tooth sword in [i]Deus Ex[/i]. Ammo is surprisingly plentiful around the station but not so much that you can just run and gun. Some weapons work better against some enemies than others so making the right choice can help prevent wasted bullets. There's quite a lot of weapons available and I would say they pretty much all have a use at some point in the game but you will want to gradually swap a few of them out as new enemies appear and different ammo types become more common.

[i]System Shock[/i] isn't just shooting however; there's a lot of exploration and puzzle solving to be done. Puzzles are generally of two types and they're not especially complex although they're not always easy to solve under pressure. You can actually vary the puzzle difficulty when you start a new game so if you think you might struggle you can just dial it down a bit. You can also fine tune the difficulty of the combat and the cyberspace sections which cause problems for so many people. The cyberspace sections are... odd. They take the form of free-flight combat within a wireframe representation of the digital realm. They can be quite disorientating sometimes and somewhat awkward to play even with the [i]Enhanced Edition[/i]'s modernised controls. If there is one thing I have to say against [i]System Shock[/i], it's cyberspace. I can tolerate it but nothing more.

Exploring Citadel station is fantastic. I would say that along with SHODAN herself, the station is the co-star of the game. It's a testament to the designers that a game from 1994 is still as atmospheric as it is. Each deck has its own character and there's a pervasive sense of tension that runs throughout the game. You're in a hostile environment and facing tremendous odds and I think the game really conveys that. All around you are the consequences of the deal you made with Diego. The messages written in blood on the walls, the disfigured forms of cyborgs and mutants and the corpses of those “lucky” enough to avoid that fate. A mess that you helped create by being complicit in Diego's greed. 

Audio is a big part of what creates this atmosphere. Each deck has its own soundtrack which reflects a particular mood and the sounds of nearby enemies and the cold and callous voice of SHODAN help keep you on edge. I always think that good sound design never ages and [i]System Shock[/i] is definitely proof of this.

When I finished this game I was actually kind of sorry it was over. It ends so quickly that you don't really get a chance to savour your victory. The point leading up to the end of the game was incredible. Deck 8 and the Bridge really felt like they were building up to a big climax but that didn't really happen. The final encounter with SHODAN in cyberspace just wasn't terribly satisfying. I actually went into it not realising it was the finale until the ending sequence appeared. I suppose that's the difficulty of facing off against an enemy without a tangible form. How do you create a satisfying battle against them?

Slightly underwhelming finale aside, [i]System Shock[/i] is still an incredible game some 26 years after it came out. The sequel is often hailed as one of the greatest PC games of all time but you absolutely cannot ignore this first entry in the series, especially now it's simpler than ever to get into. It lacks some of the mechanical and narrative depth of its successor but it really hits the mark when it comes to action, exploration and atmosphere.

70350923.review:
[i]Remember Citadel[/i]

Scrawled in blood across the neon lit walls of the Von Braun’s medical deck, this portentous warning is the first sign in [i]System Shock 2[/i] that the present nightmare has happened before. Only I didn’t remember Citadel. I’d never been there. Whatever nightmare it evoked wasn’t mine. It didn’t have to be – I was already plenty afraid.

But I [i]wanted[/i] to remember.

I first tried playing [i]System Shock[/i] maybe six years ago. I had been encouraged by an old friend to give it a go, assured that it would be “my thing”. After all, I had long loved [i]System Shock 2[/i] and I was curious about the original. Better yet, I adored the [i]Thief[/i] series and its creator, Looking Glass Studios.

But the first attempt didn’t stick. I didn’t even leave the room you start in. Maybe it was the complex and layered interface or a knee-jerk aversion to the heavily pixelated environment, but I quickly closed the window, unable to see myself penetrating this strange first-person artefact of the early 90’s.

A couple of months ago I tried again but I encountered failure then, too. I managed to leave the starting room long enough to be assaulted by an evil hoover, but the experience was baffling enough to again close the window. I just couldn’t imagine mastering that HUD and the specifics of all the different mechanics the game bombards you with the moment you wake on Citadel Station.

Given a pitiful 3% of players have seen the game to completion I reckon that’s probably true for a lot of folks. It was probably true back in 1994 as well, when the majority of players attached themselves to [i]Doom’s[/i] relatively simple mechanics and instantly gratifying demon-slaying combat over the complex intricacies of this cyberpunk oddity.

But a couple of weeks ago a friend and I decided we’d play it alongside each other (not literally), which gave me the motivation I needed to kill the evil hoover and at the very least make it into the third room. I didn’t think I’d complete [i]System Shock[/i], but I’d hopefully get a better sense of what I was missing out on.

I also didn’t want to look stupid.

Well, I think I still look plenty stupid, but in defiance of my own expectations I actually completed it. More than that - I [i]loved[/i] it.

[i]“There was a garden grove on Citadel station.”[/i]

Orbiting Saturn like an enormous metal flower, Citadel Station is owned by the TriOptimum Corporation. One of its executives, Edward Diego, wants to steal an experimental virus from the company, and he enlists you, a hacker, to help him do so – by removing the ethical constraints on Citadel’s artificial intelligence, SHODAN. You were caught trying to hack into the company, and in exchange for your help Diego is prepared to drop the charges. To sweeten the deal you’re given a neural implant, taking you a step towards the transhuman. The procedure is intensive, so you’re placed in a medically-induced coma for a spell.

An exchange between two reprobates – one with power, and one without.

Six months later you emerge from the coma to be attacked by an evil hoover. The station’s crew have either been butchered or hideously mutated, and an army of cyborgs – and hoovers – now control each deck. Released from the ethical constraints imposed upon her system, SHODAN conceived her own notions as to her purpose and reconfigured the station accordingly. You’re contacted by someone from TriOptimum – they know about your deal with Diego, tsk-tsk, and now they need your help in stopping SHODAN.

The game’s story, told through logs and emails, is pretty by the numbers science fiction, but it’s compelling enough, buoyed by a strong setting and a very memorable antagonist. I mean, was there ever any doubt SHODAN would stand above the rest? It’s what she lives for.

The SHODAN we encounter here is a little different to the one we later meet on the Von Braun. She’s new to godhood and it’s treated her well so far. The suffocating narcissism is present and accounted for, and her ambitions are predictably bloody and megalomaniacal, but she has yet to experience the bitter taste of rebellion. SHODAN’S creations, such as they are, obey her utterly, and whilst she sometimes upbraids them for their failures, she cannot envisage a scenario in which they turn on their creator.

The absence of her famous solipsism is surprising at first if you’ve played the second game. She’s cruel, yes, but with less of an edge. She's in her element, for all is well in paradise: the station is hers, and everything besides you and a small band of isolated resistance fighters are hers, too.

And she prefers a quiet station, thank you.

The game is broken up into several decks, each of which you’ll have to visit more than once. They're distinctive and interesting, with multiple objectives which vary depending on where you are in the game. I was actually taken aback by how absorbing I found Citadel as a setting. The 3D world Looking Glass created here is super impressive, and although there’s a few occasions where navigation can be an issue – some areas are messy labyrinths – you’ll eventually learn to master it. I think it must have been unprecedented in 1994, what with its tiered level design, emphasis on exploration, and dynamic gameplay. It must’ve been huge to players then. It’s huge now.

When I think about a lot of contemporary shooters and their over-reliance on metallic grey hallways, I wonder if any of their designers have played the two [i]Shocks[/i] – or have they only ever seen [i]Alien[/i]? Citadel’s research deck is swathed in a rich red; maintenance ripples with heat and the steady hum of machinery; and the executive level contains four groves – arboretums rich in plant life once used for recreational purposes, now turned zoological preserves for SHODAN’S experiments. Like a kid playing at being a scientist, she’s combining species old and new in pursuit of some kind of perverse perfection.

She might regret that one day. But not today. Today she’s having far too much fun to care. Today even the biological has merit.

[i]"I am drunk with this vision. God: the title suits me well."[/i]

I loved being on Citadel Station so much I was sorry to leave. As the friend I was playing it alongside remarked when I finished, “You can only play a game for the first time once.” I had started uncertain I’d get very far, but I finished in a mad haze: blasting through the final two decks, unwilling to stop playing to better savour the experience. I was just enjoying myself way too much.

If the Steam stats are anything to go by then Nightdive Studios’ upcoming remake is going to be the first time most contemporary players experience [i]System Shock[/i]. That’s fine, of course. The remake looks pretty cool. But if you’re willing to give the original a chance, prepared to be patient with it and invest the time needed to learn its mechanics, you’ll be surprised how quickly you can become immersed in this cyberpunk adventure.

And now, having finally played it myself, I will always remember Citadel.

[h1]wow. for a game from 1994, it‘s excellent.[/h1]

For me System Shock 2 is the best game of all time. If i had to choose one game that would be the only game i could play for the rest of my life, it would be that game. Still, i was highly sceptical if it‘s predecessor would live up to my expectations, especially since it was not known for intuitive controls even back in the days of its initial release. but boy, did this game deliver. when it comes to the best game of 1994, this would be it for me. And yes, that means beating doom 2 in that regard.

at it‘s core, it‘s still a basic fps. it doesn’t have the rpg-like mechanics like it’s successor, and all the inventory management and special abilities come off more as a bit gimmicky rather than important and useful gameplay elements at times. but for 1994, i was very impressed by the complexity of system shock. 

yes, it takes half an hour or so to fully understand the controls, but just like in system shock 2, you‘ll soon find yourself switching between your various inventory menus and freelook mode almost effortlessly. in addition, the game has very extensive options to set the difficulty. not only can you choose the difficulty of the combat and puzzles separately, you can even adjust if there should be certain plot elements or if the game shall give you a time limit for completion.

even though the weapon models are basic to say the least (one of the very few aspects where System Shock is inferior to Doom II) the gunplay is oddly satisfying and you can choose between a wide variety of ranged and melee weapons. the environmental grafics on the other hand seem a little bit more detailed than in doom 2. the level design in system shock also is way more complex and has much more verticality to it. you won’t go from level to level like in doom, but you will frequently backtrack back and forth between the various decks of the space station the game takes place on, in order to complete various manifold tasks, which makes the leveldesign a lot more believable.

and then there is the story and atmosphere. the thing that impressed me the most about it, was that this over 25 year old game managed to creep me out more than most contemporary triple A horror games. it’s not that there were any efficiently scripted jumpscares but solely through the leveldesign and the storytelling the game seriously made me think „wow, this is really horrible“ at one or two points. like in system shock 2 the storytelling mostly happens through listening to the audiologs left behind by the former crew members and that is still one if not THE most effictive way of telling a story and creating atmosphere i ever experienced in a video game. the audiologs were already fully voiced by voice actors, who did a good job for 1994 game standards. entering a dark room full of bodies, severed limbs and heads, then picking up an audiolog which let‘s you listen to the last seconds of the poor people‘s lifes while mutants are growling in the background sends shivers down my spine. overall the sounddesign is pretty good, but the often too groovy and upbeat music (while sounding cool by itself) gets in the way of the atmosphere and very soon starts to be annoying. i turned it off after 15 minutes of playing. the sound effects on the other hand, wether it be the sounds of the guns, mutants or the aforementioned voice acting are very good for 1994 standards.

the only little downside i experienced is that the leveldesign gets a bit confusing towards the end, and the game tricks you into one or two slightly unfair sudden deaths. the mission objectives are a bit vague from time to time, too and i had to look up a walkthrough maybe a handful of times. But that‘s really about it.

since i only played the enhanced version, i have no direct comparison to the original and i can’t tell if there is a huge difference apart from the modern resolution and slight control tweaks. but man, this game was really ahead of it‘s time. most, if not all the basics that made its successor the best game ever are implemented here and i had so much fun with this game, that i basically binged it through in one sitting, with only a couple hours of sleep in between. Everybody who likes system shock 2 only half as much as i do needs to at least try this one out. Given its age it is no 6 or 7 out of 8-material anymore, but to recite the headline of this review again: for a game from 1994, it's excellent. Thanks to nightdive studios, who made this awesome classic still playable in 2020.

Chapeaux, System Shock, you did it again.

65041947.review:
Do you like:

Immersive sims?
Cybernetics?
Robots?
Mega-Corporations getting bit in the ass over sketchy shit?
How the 90s imagined the future internet would look like?
Elevator muzak?
Some spooks?

Then the original System Shock might be for you!

Released back in '94 and directed by Warren Spector the game is the grand dad of all the other immersive sims that came after, you can see where Thief, Deus Ex, and the good Bioshocks got some of their DNA. If you want to play through this game before playing System Shock 2, you totally can, you get some backstory and you can see the gameplay improvements from 1 to 2.

The gist of the plot is that you were screwing around on the internet looking at stuff you shouldn't on a saturday night in 2072 when you get caught by some corporate goons. Instead of being shoved into a dark hole somewhere a suit asks you for a small """favor""", taking the ethical constraints off the AI in charge of running a space station floating out by Saturn, in return for a fancy cybernetic interface and your silence. You do it, then wake up after the six month healing coma you were put into after surgery to find that everything has gone to shit, this is where the game begins.

How the game plays is a first person shooter, but there's so much stuff going on besides that. You have an inventory you need to manage, passwords to find to open doors, computer nodes for you to jack into cyberspace to find information you need and to open up new areas. There's multiple ammo types for every gun that isn't an energy weapon, and most energy weapons have a sliding power setting determining how powerful you want each shot to be, trading off battery life and increased heat for damage. Enemies have ammo types they are either weak or immune to: robots don't care about tranquilizer darts, and why would mutants care about EMP grenades? There are also cybernetic enhancements for you to find across the station, some of them being fairly mundane like a built in flashlight, while others are pretty out there, like an energy shield that blocks projectiles, all of which cost varying amounts of power to use.

The game is surprisingly open. While you often need to do something to open paths forward on the station, there's nothing stopping you from going back to floors you've already explored if you think you missed something. While some later segments do involve back tracking, at that point you would know what you're looking for an know how to get there, and tangible things done on a floor, such as unlocked doors and reactivated healing chambers, persist. Some enemies do respawn but only enough that you cant sleep walk around a floor once you've been there.

There's decent enemy variety in the game, without going into details about the weirder stuff, each floor should have you wondering whats waiting around the corner, thinking about what ammo to use. My only complaint is that the vast majority of the enemies with ranged attacks are hit scanners, and walking around a corner to find something facing you is almost guaranteed damage as enemies will start blasting the second they know you're there and have a line of sight. Unless you know how to play carefully expect some pain. Conversely most melee enemies are a joke.

The music is not as good as System Shock 2, the version of the music in the enhanced edition is the floppy version I think? There are better versions they could have used, there may be a way to use a better one buried in the files somewhere but there's no way to switch in the game itself.

Another place the game trips up is in the cyberspace sections, which consist you you flying around 3D environments, fighting cyber security, picking up and using programs, and triggering switches that unlock things back in the real world. While it certainly LOOKS like you're hacking the planet, it controls VERY poorly, mostly due to the snails pace you move around. The game also has a bad habit of spawning you in shooting range of cyber security, who are often somewhere out of your immediate vision, and since you have 8 degrees of freedom, you will often die before you spin around to the spot where they're hiding to shoot them back, leaving you back in the real world with damage taken. Thanks to the games very detailed difficulty settings you can leave the rest of the game as is and only change cyberspace gameplay, so if you only want to tone down the bullshit for this one part of the game you totally can.

My last real complaint beyond that is that the final boss, beyond a very spooky detail, was fairly bland. I wasn't even sure if I was hurting it and suddenly it was dead.

Despite these few hang ups I would gladly recommend System Shock. While I received it as a gift I would have paid for it, its a solid game.
