If you’re tired of the old formula of walk into a room, shoot a bunch of baddies, move to the next room, and mind-numbingly repeat until you find a new weapon or move to a new environment to keep it interesting, die to end the pain, or beat the game mindlessly... then consider System Shock.

	This game is pure genius from the minds of Looking Glass Studios in 1994, and updated by Nightdive Studios in 2015. Part FPS, part point-and-click, all immersive RPG. You’re dropped into a classic sci-fi action, horror setting: a space station where everything that could go wrong, has gone wrong. Looking-Glass actually pioneered this trope, and have inspired games and probably movies by the story they told. In fact, the Deus Ex games (made by Looking Glass as well) and BioShock series were heavily inspired by SS1 and SS2.

	In game, you’re a Hacker, arrested by Trioptimum for trying to get into their systems, and the executive Edward Diego asks you if you can do a little hacking job for him in exchange for your freedom and some high-grade cybernetic implants. You hack Trioptimum’s Citadel Station AI, removing it’s ethical restraints and giving control of it to Diego, and as promised, you’re given the surgical implants and put in recovery sleep for 6 months. But the AI, SHODAN, proves to hard to control by Diego...

	When you wake up, the station is infested by mutants, cyborgs, robots, and other indescribable horrors who are out for your blood. You are, after all, the Hacker that gave SHODAN true life, and you’re the only one alive on board to put a stop to all the horrors the wannabe, delusional deity has planned for humanity.

	This game is nothing like what games are today, and it has absolutely no hand-holding. The game features the first “audio logs” left behind by the doomed crew, and your progression relies heavily upon them, as much of your objectives and clues as to what to do and where to go are found in your large supply of audio files left behind by the recently mangled. The emergent gameplay involves survival, exploration at your own pace (unless you play the harder timed mode), story, and objectives. Get ready to be confused, because this game holds the mother of all maze-like level design, but if you really look into your audio logs and emails (if you’ve actually found most of them), then you should be fine with a little connecting of the dots... or you could lookup a walkthrough, but that sort of destroys immersion. The game is intended to immerse you within the world and the horrors within, despite the brightly colored and ancient graphics and mostly annoying, dated music.

	Speaking of graphics and music, do you remember what the game DOOM looked like? Well, SS1, like any game from around then, especially DOS games, looks absolutely horrible. And I brought up DOOM as the example for better graphics AND music. However, the game isn’t too hard to look it after you get used to the older style, and the  arcadey, pixel pop that plays in the background isn’t too bad, especially if you lower music volume a tad and clear Level One, asap (it’s the worst one in my opinion). The controls and HUD are also a bit confusing at first, but with some practice it’s easy enough to get the swing of. So many buttons, things in your inventory, guns, ammo, items, audio logs, key cards, emails, software, games, and upgrades to use.

	This game really is a wonder, and it gave me the same sort of excited feeling I got when playing Hollow Knight (which I also highly recommend), from learning the gameplay to exploring, surviving, and progressing. With each door I opened I was drawn in, falling right into the story, and I quickly became addicted until I had beaten SHODAN. —I will warn you that the ending *is a little disappointing*, because all that you’ve gone through to get to the final battle... it’s really not anything to sweat over... it’s easy. Which isn’t something I expected when I saw the end screen.— But the game is totally worth it, and there’s technically a couple boss battle situations, ambushes, and surprises that make up for it. The further you go, the more it begins to dawn on you that the digital “deity” has it out for you, whether you’re ready or not. Its all up to you to take her down with all your technological knowhow, especially since it really is your fault that SHODAN is in such a state of System Shock.

Playing this game for the first time 25 years after its release, it can be a little rough! There's a lot that the game won't tell you, and sometimes figuring it out can feel super rewarding. Other times, a little frustrating. The controls are about as wonky as everyone describes them to be, but you get used to them pretty quick. The lack of hand-holding is great, but if you're trying to keep from using any walkthroughs, you may find yourself in my shoes, retracing entire levels trying to figure out what you might have passed by on accident. I was able to finish the game without checking a guide, but I honestly feel like it was only just barely. There are a few times when it seems like the game will unlock a certain door because you've made unrelated progress elsewhere, and that really does suck. My biggest recommendations would be to read the game manual, and if you're feeling stuck, go back through and listen to your logs and emails. Chances are that will remind you of something you forgot to do. 

A few things you might not know until you're hours into the game... Press S to move faster in cyberspace. You can climb a handful of walls in addition to ladders- experiment with cables and vines. Grenades will explode if you shoot them- if you have a hard time evading their blast radius, try throwing them without arming them and then shooting them on the ground from a safe distance. You can shoot most enemies from around cover before they're capable of shooting back. Cameras you've passed are marked on your map with a red dot. You can view your ammo count for all weapons by choosing "ITEM" in the MFD and clicking on a firearm.

I remapped "fire" from the enter button to the left click mouse and had a much better time of it.

56601264.review:
I will admit I'm a very particular person when it comes to FPS games. I generally don't enjoy the traditional military shooters, I prefer my fps to be in one two categories. Fast paced circle strafing carnage, like DOOM and Painkiller, or slow, brutal and claustrophobic  crawls through atmospheric hellscapes, like Bioshock, Half Life and Metro 2033. System shock is one of the latter. Indeed, system shock is pretty much the granddaddy of the latter's entire genre. And, with the enhanced edition giving us a few small changes (Mainly mouse look, and the ability to to full screen the game) we discover that Granddad is surprisingly limber. 

First the plot, as it is the fulcrum around which it all swings. In the cyberpunk future, a hacker gets caught attempting to hack a large corporation.  Rather than prosecuting, they hire him to turn the moral constraints off a Station AI. He is given an operation for a state of the art implant, and put into a six month healing coma, hidden in the lower decks. He wakes to find that the majority of the stations inhabitants are now smeared all over the walls and floors of the station, and that the AI has decided that she is now god. 

The plot, whilst not the deepest, is utterly engrossing, because the game is very very good at immersing the player. The sound design on the various mutants and robots is great, and providing you turned the annoying techno music off it will be the only sound you hear besides gunfire and doors opening and closing. Controls are intentionally clunky- the player has to inventory manage in real time, and will have some difficulty aiming their gun as they do. In order to aim ones weapon accurately, one must forfeit the ability to turn. It may sound like a somewhat asinine choice, but it works wonders for the afformentioned immersion- you can really believe that you are a random out of shape hacker barely able to fire a weapon, and any attempt at reloading or checking your inventory is always made tense by the fact that a mutant could very easily run around the corner and bite your nose off while your are trying to work out where you put the landmines. The lighting is also very good. At more than one point I found myself panicking and firing round after round into a stain on the wall in the murkily lit room. One section I will heap particular praise on was in the second level, where a very tall enemy is standing in a room backlit by a screen. If you miss a shot, the screen will break and plunge the room into darkness, lit only by the flashes of gunfire. The game is full of brilliant little touches like this. It also has a surprisingly high number of gameplay features- Several different hacking minigames, ranging from wire matching to flying through a fully 3d cyberspace,  night vision, vision on the back of your head, rocket boots, jet pack.. the list goes on and on, although I think I name dropped the best features. 

Amazingly for a game that's as old as I am, the levels are surprisingly well detailed. The came came out only a year after Doom, and it's level design is about a decade ahead. (Because, as much as I love Doom, it is pretty much a dozen hours of running down a brown corridor). Every level feels very distinct just to look at, and each has a very complicated layout. Even better, there are sections on some that open up later on in the game, encouraging you to go back and explore earlier areas. You can go up and down most of the lifts at any time, and it works wonders for making Citadel Station feel like a living place. Well, I suppose a dead place considering the fact that the crew now more closely resemble the carpet.

But, for me at least, the game's most memorable attribute is it's villain. The AI SHODAN (Voiced magnificently by Terri Brosius) is a cold, implacable and brutal foe. Her gaze is constantly felt by her omnipresent eyes- The ship's security cameras, and through her frequent messianic rants to her cyborgs and her sardonic and mocking commentary on the player's actions. There are a couple of moments which I will not spoil, but will say that my jaw nearly hit the floor at some of the things that she does to hinder the player. The majority of her minions are all sprites, and generally look very nice. They are well detailed and have a decent range of animations- enough that I generally stopped noticing them as sprites, and just saw them as part of the game, which is an achievement in itself.

Although, I will give full disclosure, and lay out a few criticisms. Mainly, the hacking minigame is both nauseating, and rather boring to play. There was one on the second to last level that I just could not complete, because I lacked the patience to try time and time again to fly the camera (With an unclear hitbox) between shapes which could kill me in two impacts. The game also builds up the Cortex Reaver as something terrible.. which it turns out to be, as I don't think one ever managed to damage me (ten out of ten for messed up design though). Some players may also dislike the respawn booths system- I was quite happy with it, as with the amount of enemies that can sometimes be thrown at the player, it was a godsend. I will note that there is also the option to simply not turn the booths on, although healing items are sparse enough that this will mean both a lot of save scumming, and a lot of trekking down to the first level and the only easily accessible healing booth in the game. The final climax is also a tad underwhelming. It earns many points for atmosphere, but it the game does end somewhat abruptly. It's a fight than can be hard or easy depending on how much you explore- I think I might have a little bit too much, as it was barely an issue for me.

Minor Criticisms set aside, in all seriousness, please try this game. it's aged incredibly well, and is a nasty, stressful, sometimes outright scary joy to play.

So, System Shock. Lesser known as its sequel System Shock 2, but was the first to do many things in the immersive sim genre today. Initially I brought this before the Source Port update and it crashed on me a fair few more times than I'd like. When I saw it was updated I gave it another try and it worked flawlessly, allowing me to complete the entire game without any issue. 

So, I started, woke up in a medical ward, and sooner than later I'm already bashing robots in with the pipe and gunning down mutants. Compared with 2, where you get a short prequel that builds your character's proficiency before waking up in the Van Brawn. There is no character building here in 1, all upgrades are predetermined and weapons are solely limited by ammo than it is your skills in using and maintaining them. So I round a corner, and see what I consider the first real enemy in the game, the Cyborg Assassins. I was able to get the first shot off before it noticed me, it died before it can do much other than chuck a shuriken at me, which I easily dodged. This doesn't really change with stronger enemies, they all have a distinct sound cue allowing you to put up your shields, lean around a corner and get the first shots in. Mouselook invalidates the struggle of combat otherwise, I suggest playing with harder combat or with the original control scheme to balance it out. 

Eventually, I happened upon a Cyberspace jack, and thrust myself into the wireframed world that is Cyberspace. This was one part not in 2, and for good reason. Navigation, while disorienting, isn't hard due to the sheer lack of obstacles save for the mine that can be easily avoided. Cyberspace serves purely to open a door leading to supplies. Despite it failing in some regards and not exactly what I expected, System Shock was still the first in its genre and was enjoyable despite this, many years after games that improved upon what it laid out released.

55177235.review: This game is the still the most fully realized immersive sim I have played. It is very different to the second game and the new prey and I feel that its design philosophy has been fundamentally misunderstood. This is a role-playing game in the sense that you play the role of a hacker stranded on a hostile space station and all systems funnel into that fantasy. Citadel Station has a logical layout that allows the player to piece together what happened and how to stop Shodan through audio logs. The world building ties into the puzzles which advance the story. This game is very tightly designed and every item and inch of the station feels intentional and meaningful. Upgrading your character is not abstracted to numbers that determine your ability to do basic functions like run or shoot guns. It was refreshing and feels more organic and well realized than every game System Shock has inspired to have an upgrade system that is determined by the items you find. It's not necessary to dump upgrade points into agility to eventually be able to jump to a ledge later on. The game has jump boots and it is your job to think through which floor they would logically be on and who would have them based on your understanding of the crew through audio logs. This makes progression satisfying and forces the player to decide which upgrades they want equipped. Ironic that this solution solves the progression problems in the following game. You are not locked down to a build, but rather the game tests your deductive reasoning to find unique and helpful items and weapons. Objectives are simple but you are not told where to go so again the game forces you to immerse yourself in the station and think like its crew. This gives you an amount of freedom that is sorely lacking in modern games, even in future games made by these developers. The Enhanced Edition adds mouse aiming support making this game very accessible and intuitive. I thought I would loathe the clunky controls but I found it more accessible than the second game. The difficulty settings are really interesting as well and it's baffling that no future games used this system. At the beginning you are asked to choose the difficulty in story, combat, hacking, and puzzles. This allows you to tailor the game to how you want to play. You can play a really complex story that requires knowledge of how to diagnose a broken relay but simple combat where enemies die in one hit, or combat could require peeking around every corner taking potshots at enemies and sneaking around when ammo is scarce, but objectives are straight forward. This game has systems and design choices that put most modern games to shame. It is definitely worth the price and worth trying. I can't remember who said it but this game is essentially Die Hard in space and it delivers on that fantasy in every way.

54831956.review:
[b]The first System Shock, but pretty much remade into Nightdive's own game engine.[/b]

The game plays almost exactly like the original, but with loads of modern features that make the gameplay downright better if not just tolerable, namely the change in controls. Unlike the original, you can map the key actions around and there's real mouse look here, making the game feel like an FPS most people are used to. Though the controls may have been modernized, they still take a bit of getting used to.

As the intro goes, it starts with showing you, a hacker, who got arrested by a mega-corporation for hacking into said mega-corporation's files. The VP of the corporation offers the hacker a deal to help him reprogram the AI, SHODAN, in exchange for a full pardon and a cybernetic upgrade. After succeeding, the hacker goes into a 6-month healing coma to heal from the upgrade. The game begins with the hacker waking up to find the space station he was on gone to hell and along the way, you see the story progress through received e-mails and audio logs.

There's a lot of techno music in the game and most of the graphics are bright in contrast, making it almost have a completely different atmosphere from the more well-known sequel. There's only one place in the game with absolutely no music and is actually very dark, but you're not there for very long.

The game plays like a small mix of dungeon crawling RPG and FPS, with a little more emphasis on the FPS as there's very little in the way of actual RPG mechanics. As an actual FPS though, it's not all that great. You can cheese most situations by just peaking around cover to the point where you can shoot enemies and their AI sometimes doesn't detect you; this is at least handy on the max difficulty settings where enemies hit hard and are increased in number. Because enemy models aren't actually 3D, it can also be hard to tell where their hitbox ends and begins, especially when viewing them from above or below.
I find the real selling point of the game to be its exploration, its lore, and how the story progresses. There are no objective markers or anything like that, so you're forced to figure out how to progress many parts of the game on your own using only what you've heard from found audio logs and received e-mails; the game needs you to have a pretty big attention span pretty much. Of course, you could just consult a walkthrough or set the game so you don't have to pay attention to these things, but then you'd be pretty much taking the core out of the game.

There are a lot of dated things in the game, but you get used to them. It's a great classic that can take maybe around a dozen hours to complete.

As someone who never touched this series until now, I think this may be the earliest-made PC game that I totally loved playing. The enhanced version makes everything easy to use on modern computers, it seems. I was playing in 1080p with no issues with control and very little jank.

It's crazy how many features the game has. It actually has more features for interfacing with the game than much more modern games of similar style like Bioshock, or the Metro series. It's pretty crazy how much detail is in here. You can turn on a device that shows you a camera that faces behind you at the bottom of the screen so you can have eyes on the back of your head. You get a jetpack. You get crazy skates that let you zip around at insane speeds while slamming enemies with your laser sword. You can lean around corners and check if there's anything there. You can lean WHILE crouching or going full prone. You get to hack into computers and enter 3-dimensional hackerspace with directional controls and a roll axis. There's a button to go between a mouse cursor and full FPS aim controls. (Make sure if you start playing that you know this key exists because you'll be needing it.) It's crazy how much detail is in the game and how much agency you have.

Speaking of the controls, you're going to have to figure them out on your own by looking at the control settings screen. However, they really give you plenty of agency to do everything you need to do in the game. The only control I thought was missing was the ability to configure equipping a specific weapon to a specific keystroke rather than having to use buttons to cycle through your current weapons.

The music is probably the most aged thing in the game. It's still running MIDI audio, which sounds incredibly jank on modern computers. You can dress it up a bit with your own MIDI soundfonts, but I don't think it really does the game justice in an audio sense. The cyberspace music tracks though, those ones are fun. The audio recordings of people living on the station and SHODAN are actually really damn nice for such an old game. 

The game is rock solid and I never saw it crash through the whole playthrough.

There's a bit of jank in that you can get caught on certain floorboards or platforms, slowing you down unexpectedly. But usually, this doesn't happen.

The storyline is easy to get into, and while being pretty straightforward, is fun to play a part of since it's got such nice lore behind it. You can tell straight away that a ton of thought was put into designing the station the game takes place on, with each level mattering for specific tasks and goals. The design of each floor of the station makes a lot of sense. The enemies aren't incredibly nuanced in the way you fight each of them, but it's fun to blow them up while going through the game's story. If I had to nitpick, I'd say a couple of areas have random spawns that are usually one of the only reasons you die after becoming competent at the game. One area specifically if you kill enough suicidal enemies hiding around the corners, a new one can spawn right beside you and blow up immediately. Those were a bit annoying.

For a 25-year-old game, the enhanced edition of this game is still really playable and has features that surpass modern games of similar style.

50010708.review:
Let me get this out of the way up front: System shock is an outstanding game. An innovative pioneer in its field held back only by its age, and the fact that it released in the shadow of the original DOOM. TLDR: It is nothing short of a tragedy that this game was overlooked when it was released. It is much more clunky and less intuitive than DOOM, but when you adjust and the motions become natural, System Shock is a game that respects the intelligence of the player, and doesn't hold their hand too much. It nails its atmosphere creating a feeling of claustrophobia, paranoia and tension with an omnipresent rogue AI who is, with good reason frequently listed as one of the greatest villains ever. If you can bear with its age and the initial learning curve of the HUD and controls, it is an incredibly enjoyable experience that will unnerve, but also thrill you with an excellent narrative and an engaging series of obstacles to overcome, despite an admittedly underwhelming final boss. Anyone who has enjoyed Deus Ex or a Shock game, especially System Shock 2, owes it to themselves to check this out and see where it all started.


As someone who played this game for the first time last year, I must say that for anyone not used to this era of game design, it is an experience. There is no hand-holding, and if you come back to a playthrough after a long hiatus it will be completely up to you to figure out where you were going and what you were supposed to be doing. Yes there are the restoration chambers which essentially eliminate any penalty for dying, but the fact that you have to find these chambers and turn them on, with switches that are not always so obvious to find is a decent balance. Moreover, there is a heavy emphasis on you, the player, exploring and piecing together what has happened, and if you have played Bioshock you will understand how this works from a narrative standpoint. What makes this game different is that there is no objective marker, there is nobody to tell you where to go or how to solve the obstacles in front of you, there are clues around in the form of audio logs and emails but it is up to you to explore and figure out how to proceed. This kind of game design that encourages the player to think, listen and explore is incredibly refreshing. However, it's usually not that difficult to figure out what you need to do, and if you get stuck the guides which can be found in the game's files are a godsend. The game does ramp up in difficulty towards the end by removing the restoration chambers, but it compensates by dropping so many first aid kits and batteries that its almost not worth mentioning.

While the graphics have not aged well, and there are a few times when you wont be able to find something that's right next to you just because its blending in with the wall, the game never fails to nail its atmosphere. The soundtrack can be 'goofy' in places but equally so, there are so many levels where the deep, quiet metronome blends seamlessly with the dark textures, the shadowy, claustrophobic, empty halls filled with nothing but corpses, abandoned machinery, and the sounds of the next cyborgs waiting to murder you. The game nails this right from level 1 and it never broke the atmosphere, or alleviate the fear I felt when turning every corner, wondering when SHODAN would spring her next trap. This is a testament to how well the game creates its atmosphere. In spite of its age, to this day it inspires fear and gives off the impression of a truly dead station.

As an omnipresent AI, SHODAN is the perfect antagonist for the setting, and it's no wonder she is repeatedly listed among the greatest villains of all time. SHODAN occupies no physical space. She is everywhere, and yet she is nowhere. She has no physical power to wield, but even knowing this she was able to strike fear into my heart as she calls out to threaten you, and ominously warn you. As the game goes on you realise her powers are indeed extremely limited, used sparingly, and of course you become more able to combat them. Yet despite all of this, SHODAN's ability to strike from anywhere, at any time contributes enormously to making the player feel paranoid and powerless, especially since she cannot be fought or killed (except in cyberspace). The corruptions in SHODAN's speech, and the ominous deep music that plays behind whenever she speaks is perfect, and reminds me of the Master from Fallout 1. It effectively conveys the feeling that you are dealing with something truly evil and malicious, but also completely beyond your comprehension. Combined with her God complex, and the almost poetic ways in which SHODAN describes her power, it all culminates in a truly fearsome, effective antagonist who will keep you guessing until the very end. While System Shock was not the first to create a narrative about a (seemingly) omnipotent AI gone rogue, it is one of the few to genuinely incite fear in me, and is of course evermore relevant in the modern day as automation and true AI come closer and closer into our reality. 

The interface is daunting, and the learning curve is steep. Once mastered it feels good, relatively quick and easy to use, but it does present a problem to anyone picking up this game for the first time, and it's no wonder that it was passed over in favour of the more intuitive simplicity of DOOM. The game however, rewards you with high levels of depth and agency in how you play the game. A range of hardware attachments can aid you, but must be managed and balanced as you have a limited amount of energy with which to use them, and an equally limited number of opportunities to charge that energy. Cyberspace and puzzles (though bland) are here as well to add an extra level of variety to the gameplay. Luckily again, there are solutions in the guides included in the bonus content if you need it. Moreover, and one of the best features of the game is that it has difficulty sliders for both of these, in addition to story and combat which allows you full reign over whether they're easy, hard or non-existent. This gives the player a level of control over their experience I've never seen before, and I loved it and wish more games could have this.

I don't expect anyone to make it through this essay, and I don't ever write reviews like this, but that should be a testament to how incredible this game really is, even today. If you did: Thank you. System Shock is a classic and with good reason. If you can stick with it to overcome its learning curve, you'll be glad you did as even today there are few games like this. SHODAN is an incredible villain, and the story and atmosphere creates an intense feeling of fear, isolation and paranoia that fully immerses you in the experience with decent gunplay to boot . If you've read this far you know what to do: go forward and experience SHODAN's rebirth into beauty on C-C-Citadel Station. Good Luck... Hacker.

8/10

[i]"In my talons, I shape clay, crafting life forms as I please. If I wish, I can smash it all. Around me is a burgeoning empire of steel. From my throne room, lines of power careen into the skies of Earth. My whims will become lightning bolts that raze the mounds of humanity. Out of the chaos, they will run and whimper, praying for me to end their tedious anarchy. I am drunk with this vision. God: the title suits me well."

- SHODAN[/i]


System Shock is a first person action-adventure game developed by Looking Glass Technologies and published Origin Systems. It was first released in September 23rd 1994 and later rereleased in September 22nd 2015 on GOG and Steam after Night Dive Studios acquired the rights of the franchise.

In this game, you play as a Hacker who was apprehended by security forces of the mega corporation TriOptimum for attempting to access protected files concering space station dubbed Citadel Station, orbiting Saturn. Instead of being thrown into prison, you were taken into Citadel Station. You were then contacted by Edward Diego, a TriOptimum executive, and offers to you a service to drop charges against you and a reward: a military-grade neural interface. Edward Diego then tasks the hacker to hack into SHODAN, the artificial intelligence (AI) that controls CItadel Station, and remove it's ethical contrainsts. After the task was completed, the Hacker is then placed into surgery for the military-grade neural interface to be implanted and is then put into a six month healing coma. With the ethical constrainsts removed, SHODAN becomes rogue, killing or transforming the personel onboard Citadel Station into mutants or cyborgs. After six months, the Hacker wakes up from his coma to find the station mostly deserted with the exception of robots, mutants and cyborgs. It is up to the player, the Hacker, to stop SHODAN once and for all.

Once you start up the game, you may find the controls hard and complicated. But when you progress through the game, you will get used to the setup. You may come across different kinds of weapons and hardware in the game that will aid you in your gameplay. There is one feature that is my favoruite, Cyberspace. You access it to unlock certain areas. 

There is a security system, where SHODAN could block you from entering certain areas in a level. You decrease a level's security level by destroying cameras and computer nodes. In some levels, SHODAN could set up traps and ambush you.

The game unfortunantely was not a commercial success and it spawned a new sequal, System Shock 2, which would become voted as the best game of all time. The game had spawned spiritual successors such the Deus Ex series and Bioshock series and was the inspiration for Prey (2017).

I would recommend this to any old school gamers out there.

I would give this game 9/10 for it's soundtrack, immersion and pacing.

Kudos to Night Dive for still updating it after all these years, and going beyond that old portable Zip we all know and love from the Looking Glass forums. 

If you can get past the awkward, not-quite-an-FPS controls & clunky inventory system you'll be rewarded with a richly atmospheric action RPG that paved the way for the genre.  You have a rich set of options for dealing with obstacles, from the weapons that have a variety of fire modes to the cybernetic implants that add new HUD & movement options. Heck, the difficulty screen even lets you set how hard you want puzzles to be. The music, art, and voice acting still hold up 20 years later - Terri Brosius deserves whatever the gaming equivalent of an Oscar is for her work on SHODAN. 

There's only a couple gripes I have. The levels are labyrinthine, with no real signposting to objectives(I'm looking at you, Cargo Deck).  There's a plethora of hitscan enemies that can murder you within seconds of entering a room, requiring save scumming in some cases to get by. That is, until you activate a respawn point - there's no downside to using these points, other than the hassle of wandering back to your point of death. This makes the difficulty curve pretty uneven. Oh, and don't get me started on the cyberspace minigame, which is the mother of all hacking minigames, and is one of the most disorienting things you will ever experience in a game. 

All that aside, if you enjoy action RPGs, this is a must-buy, and it's more accessible than ever nowadays.

This game is over 20 years old. Some of its design choices are obviously a product of its time, however the game is polished enough so that rather than showing the game's age, they highlight its clever use of what computer games could do at the time. 
And what System Shock does is survival-horror at its best. Not beacuse it feels scary today, but because it provides the player with motivation in subtle ways.
It locks the player within a huge, closed, setting, with just enough guidance to push through. While the narrative provided by the audio logs is weak, it serves the game by directing the player without actually ordering him around. 
The game's plot does provide a sense of ever-present danger, while the monsters present an imminent danger, and running out of ammo or energy seems like a real option even though the game balances that. 
Finally, the game creates a sense of realism by including games within the game. The Cyberspace experience is truly unique - well polished (note the music in the hallways between the rooms), not overused, and with just enough connection to the "outside" world.  There are other minigames and puzzles that between the exploration and combat, creating variation that strengthens Citadel Station as a setting. 
Kudos to nightdive for porting this gem to today's computers. I've had no issue with controls and not a single crash or error during the game.
I've played for 20-30 hours, but it's quite possible to finish in less than 20.

44693891.review:
System Shock: Enhanced Edition is a first-person science-fiction exploration-based action-adventure game developed by Looking Glass Studios for the unnamed System Shock engine, and re-released by Night Dive Studios via the KEX Engine. Set in the year 2072, the player takes control of an unnamed hacker who awakes from a six-month long medical coma on board a desolate space-station overrun by the biomechanical creations of the AI SHODAN.

Few games in 1994 were as forward-looking as Looking Glass Studios' System Shock, with regards to both its cyberpunk narrative and its game design sensibilities. Playing through the 10-14 hour long campaign, now easier than ever, unleashes an unprecedented presentation of considered design, creative scenarios and thoughtful storytelling. The techniques and technical details almost feel anachronistic with their modern standards for guiding and challenging the player. The moody worldbuilding of Citadel (System Shock's space station) is still captivating, still authentically lived-in and narratively grounded as the end result of the engagingly told backstory. Amidst vocal email messages and scattered audiologs, the title features genuinely compelling vocal performances, with a pace of storytelling and presentation which gradually reveals an engaging, complex and startlingly fluid and confident story which sticks the landing by the end. The level design, while dense and mazelike, is kept navigable through aesthetic variety and recognizable landmarks. Meanwhile, the gradual escalation of stakes in both the gameplay and plot is masterful; SHODAN, who's menacing personality and imposing power wouldn't be replicated again, presents a dungeon-master-like sadism, and the cat-and-mouse progression of the player’s rivalry with her is a real delight. 

Thematically, System Shock's world is about pure and fantastical technology misused by ethically compromised individuals. From the morally bankrupt businessman Edward Diego, evocative of self-serving corporate thugs like Burke from Aliens, to the player character whose involvement in the main conflict can't be ignored. Even the villain herself, although not a human, wields technology and innovation in service of her own ego and power. The world that System Shock’s vivid and absorbing backstory paints is a gritty, believable science-fiction society reminiscent of cyberpunk classics like Bladerunner and RoboCop. Unique to System Shock’s tone is the abrasive “techno-horror” of its soundscape and designs, pitting the player against mewling, murmuring, grotesquely mutilated enemies with cybernetic additions bolted onto their bodies without regard for the form or function of the human animal. The chilling body-horror implications shine through, even while obscured by System Shock’s rudimentary visuals, even to the modern day. Meanwhile, the tone and presentation of System Shock is playfully lethal and adventurous, delighting in subverting and compromising the player while allowing itself to be vulnerable enough for satisfying triumph on the player’s part. This mirrors the development of the player’s relationship with SHODAN, as her multipart plans and protective fortifications get meticulously unraveled by the player, but not without a fight.

I spend so many words on the tone and impressions of System Shock in order to impress upon the reader that there really is an adventure to be had which is engrossing, demanding and precisely put together. The full campaign is more than the sum of its parts, creating a journey that is at once perfectly scripted and player-authored, and the effect this has on the player’s experience is profound in a way that struggles to be matched even today. But accessing the sum total of what System Shock has to offer comes with a not insignificant investment. There’s a significant learning curve at the very start of the game just to get acquainted with the controls, and that's before learning and adjusting to the various in-game systems and mechanics. But the controls, as they’re implemented in the Enhanced Edition, don’t hold System Shock back. Once the player masters the interface and keybinds, the sheer fidelity of movement the avatar has at their disposal contributes to the title's immersion greatly. Simply put, if you can hold a pose in real life, you can probably recreate that pose in System Shock.

Despite coming out the same year as Super Metroid, System Shock is essentially a first-person metroidvania game set in an enclosed space station. Progressing through the story requires the player to travel back and forth between multiple areas, while obtaining collectables and permanent upgrades, such as keycards, new abilities, radiation shields, jet-boots, etc. Backtracking remains engaging through the presence of multiple distinct routes through each area, and a steady mechanical tension which keeps the player from disconnecting from the immediate moment. Unfortunately, with this openness comes a near-constant ambiguity as to what the player’s current objective is. Occasionally, they might receive a vocal email from either SHODAN or an allied character, which will usually describe the basic impressions of what is currently at stake and how to avoid it, while the level design shoulders some of the burden. But most of the heavy lifting is carried by audiologs found in the environment, which can be easy to overlook, forget or ignore.

That being said, once the player does have a handle over the current mission, the sheer amount of variety is often impressive and thrilling. Some missions require the player to simply make their way to a specific location against all odds, while others require them to hit multiple different corners of the map (either in a specific order or in whichever order the player chooses). The open-ended-ness of the game's design allows for a degree of strategizing and improvisation which means that repeat playthroughs will barely resemble each other, despite the campaign feeling remarkably guided and curated, and oftentimes the player will inadvertently perform a few steps towards completing a future mission in the downtime of a previous one. By the end of the game, the player develops a very intimate, organic sense of familiarity and control over the layout of the gameworld. In the 90's, this was the maze-like acquaintanceship that players developed with Doom levels or the dungeons from Ultima Underworld. Today, the authenticity of purpose within grounded spaces and the player-authored, emergent encounters within those spaces paint System Shock’s space station as the natural ancestor of Deus Ex, Prey and even Bioshock’s gameworlds.

With the features introduced in the Enhanced Edition — hi-res and widescreen support, new keybind options and other quality of life additions — System Shock stands tall today as a triumphant citadel elevated over its peers and even some of its successors. Back in 1994, Looking Glass Studios dared to ask what potential the future of gaming held, and were even more daring as to answer it themselves. The accessibility afforded by the Enhanced Edition doesn’t go so far as to redefine or unfairly limit the ambitions of the original title for modern audiences, only sanding off the rougher edges to make it that much easier to grasp. But even with these sanded edges, the title can prove to be not so much dated as it is a prediction of a future which never came — a present day where gaming was focused on precision, fidelity of movement and position, and a Dungeons and Dragons-like freedom within a massive, deadly playspace. As such there’s a sort of startling future-shock which can overwhelm new players, made even more dissonant and anachronistic by the aged visuals and presentation. Regardless, System Shock was, and still is, a revelation, pioneering its immersive-sim genre while leaving behind a gripping legacy of thrilling action, creative problem solving and player agency which is yet to be truly matched.

I played System Shock way back in the mid-90s and was blown away by it. The technological brilliance, the incredible atmosphere, the thrilling story packed with twists, the massive range of playing options to suit different playstyles, and so on, it all added together to create one of the most important and formative experiences of my gaming life.

The newly updated version of the Enhanced Edition brings System Shock into the 21st century. This is a remarkable achievement: this game looks, sounds, plays, and feels authentically like System Shock, but with updated screen resolution, improved lighting, intuitive controls. This is still the original game, but streamlined and improved, all without compromosing that core experience that was so important to me and millions of other 90s PC gamers.

Another game coming from Looking Glass Technologies (the creators of the famed Ultima Underworld duology) which was formerly called Looking Glass Studios, System Shock sees the player controlling an unnamed hacker who is named by the player which is very ironic, when you really think about it.

You, the player character, were caught trying to hack into the TriOptimum something-or-other (I honestly forget what) but it was big, bad, and you heard voices in your head for almost a week, at least. You awake from a six-month healing coma, as a man named Diego wipes your record clean for a small task, a favor, if you will... hack into SHODAN's mainframe and get him some of that sexy program so that he may sell it on the black market, to the Russians, I believe. Problem is, you disabled SHODAN's morality code in doing so, causing her to make some questionable decisions about her new life, while you sleep in the belly of the beast (that is to say, in the Citadel Station Healing Bay) where SHODAN will fire a laser and destroy all the major cities on earth until her demands are met.

Gameplay wise, System Shock feels very similar to the two Ultima Underworld games, which is both funny and ironic, considering that Looking Glass' higher ups were saying that they were suffering from burnout after the development of Ultima Underworld 2. You play the game in first-person view (again, similar to Ultima Underworld) and a lot of the controls are the same, only assigned to different buttons. Okay, so they aren't similar at all, but if you can quickly adapt and master the controls (or if playing the enhanced edition) just alter them to your liking. Oh, and make sure to remember that if you want mouse look enabled, just press E in the Enhanced Edition (don't know the Classic version's mouse look button) and DON'T HOLD THE E BUTTON! Just one click will do.

Musically, the game sounds like the developers went to an electronica bar, got drunk, and used the sounds they heard to make the game's music, and I gotta be honest, my ears aren't bleeding... much. Seriously, though, the first level, at least, does have something of an electronica beat to it.

Graphics-wise, it does resemble the original DOS-era System Shock, but the graphics are cleaner and sharper-looking, though still pretty pixel-ly, especially up close, and could've been better, but graphics honestly don't matter that much. They work fine and you can tell what everything is supposed to be.

So far, although only in level 1 of the game, it's shaping up to be a pretty solid experience as far as I can tell. Hopefully it'll stay that way, too.

After starting up the game countless times, learning Level 1 and 2 like the back of my hand, and then dropping the game out of feeling overwhelmed time and time again over the years, I have finally beaten the game and can give my actual thoughts on it.

This game is hella good.

I never would have thought to describe this game as fun, or even nearly as good as System Shock 2, which I love dearly and play at least twice a year, but that has changed. This game is an absolute classic.

[b][u]Story[/u][/b]
The story is incredible.
If you're someone who enjoys Prey, BioShock, System Shock 2, etc. then you know what you're in for. 
Shodan is an excellent villain, and feels almost like and eldritch horror deity. She is constantly 5 steps ahead of you, while experimenting with the deceased crew members; turning them into bio-mechanical horrors.

What really surprised me is how she made System Shock 2 Shodan look like Diet Shodan, or Great Value Shodan. I really liked her performance in SS2, but in this, she is actually [i]the[/i] star of the show. A relentless AI that is just constantly talking about how she is going to peel the skin off your bones slowly while her robotic minions feast upon your still living body.

[b][u]Gameplay[/u][/b]
The gameplay admittedly isn't super great, at least in the beginning.
The first few weapons like the pipe, the dart gun, laser blaster, and basic pistol are all very underwhelming feeling, and the enemies themselves seem more like nuisances. As you get further into the game, you get more and more weapons to play with, abilities, and much more overwhelming foes. 
This, coupled with the fact that you are slowly learning how to efficiently play the game makes for some high octane fun that became straight addicting.

By the last level, I had mastered the guns and health/energy management, and was quite sad when the ending credits hit, as the game had become incredibly fun, with me now able to fly around corners and blast mutant cyborgs in the face with a rail gun at mach speed. This kind of shares a spot with SS2 as well, as the gameplay [i]also[/i] picks up about half-way through that game too.

If you find yourself not loving the gameplay, seriously keep pushing. 
Once I did, it became worth it.
What I think really helped it shine is the new Source Port that is now default for the Enhanced Edition. The game plays so smooth, looks super sharp, and the controls were remapped to actually play like an FPS game, with a few oddities here and there. I absolutely do NOT recommend playing the classic version first for "authenticity". It controls terribly, and does not run very smooth.

If you absolutely MUST play the classic OG version, go find the old version of the Enhanced Edition, or play System Shock Portable. Anything that has mouse look, because even with mouse look on Normal difficulty, this game can tear you a new one.

[b][u]Sound/ Music[/u][/b]
The sounds of this game are deeply embedded into my brain.
They're all super crunchy late-90's stock sound effects that range from sounding pretty good, to crumpled up paper. That goes for both enemies and guns.
The UI effects all sound pretty good, with some high tech plinking when you click something, and some nice sounds when you get an email or a new voice log.

The music in this game fucking [b]slaps[/b] though.
It's all midi through Microsoft GS Wavetable Synth (unless you use a SC-55 plugin), but it just bops, and still manages to sound awesome. It's like some weird kind of cyber jazz, and once again gets really slammin' once you get to the further levels like Engineering and Executive.

[b][u]Final Thoughts[/u][/b]
I didn't go super in-depth with this interview, as I'm just writing this immediately after beating it, but if you want some deeper thoughts, just look through the reviews.

Otherwise, this game was stellar, and I can definitely see myself replaying this one at least once a year, or at least maybe when I do my bi-annual System Shock 2 playthroughs. The story is wild, the gameplay gets super thrilling, and the music slaps.

What else could you want?
For a score, I'd give this a [b]9.1/10[/b].

Even if System Shock is an old game that brought a lot of innovation at the time, the controls are overcomplicated and focus is all over the place. The game has a nice atmosphere and music, but the rest is either mediocre or below it. The lack of focus is because this game fancies itself a "methodical" shooter, meaning you have to look around corners to shoot enemies, since you can't take armed enemies head-on, or you'll die very quickly. But this approach ends up being really tedious, since the game is huge enough as it is, and there are a ton of enemies. Worst of all, they respawn, so you can't just kill everything on a floor to look for items calmly. You're constantly kept on your toes, but not as good as let's say, Doom on Nightmare difficulty. That's because the spaces to fight are very cramped (corridors), so you'll find yourself dreading combat, specially at level 3.

Another part I want to talk about is Cyberspace. Those sections bring nothing to the game except annoyance. I guess they took cues from the Sprawl Trilogy (a trilogy of books written by William Gibson), but those sections are very poorly thought out. You're being constantly pulled to something, and you don't really have much control of anything. You'll end up dying a few times to learn how to best use your resources here.

The game has dreadful combat, but it ends up being rather easy because after you activate a certain machine, there's no penalty for dying. You can scavenge items and ammunition from enemies, but except for Medi patches (health), you can stock on so much of everything else that you don't really have any use for it.

I did like a few things about the game, and those were:
- music
- atmosphere
- map system (you can write messages pinpointing places of interest)
- the audio logs can be nice, but I guess someone forgot to transcribe them properly (the words almost never match what is being said)

Anyway, the Enhanced Edition only changes a few things. You can now use mouselook, which makes a few areas much faster, there are more resolution options, and I heard one particular password is always the same.

PROTIP: READ THE MANUAL BEFORE PLAYING!

This game is phenomenal. Very ahead of its time.

I was born in 1992 so I had no idea about System Shock as it was originally released in 1994. I was playing Sesame Street PC games around this time. Now I see why Nightdive chose to remake it. Not only is this game amazing but it's fresh to me even though it's over 20 years old. There are many elements of this game which have been copied by others to this day.

{ ~ First Impressions ~ }

The Enhanced edition comes with the manual and the Classic edition. You'll want to give the manual a read through. I haven't figured out a convenient way to view the manual while in-game besides alt-tabbing or printing it out.

The Enhanced edition has improved image and sound quality. The soundtrack sounds way better in the Enhanced edition than the Classic.

This game offers replay value by allowing you to change various settings before starting a new game such as...
...the complexity of the plot and objectives
...you have the option to impose a time limit on yourself
...you can alter the combat difficulty and behavior of enemies.
...you can make puzzles harder or easier

{ ~ Gameplay ~ }

This game has a pertinent and interesting dystopian storyline, cool setting and map layout, interesting puzzles, fun combat, looting, various items with various effects offering various playstyles, and more. It's very immersive.

You are required to fight, recover important data, and bypass technological security systems in order to navigate the space station and complete game-progressing objectives.

> You need to analyze and be aware of your surroundings.
> There is no handholding.
> Looting, inventory management, unlocking doors, and most hacking is done in real time.
> Enemies respawn.
> I don't think there's any cutscenes in this game besides the intro and end cutscenes.

{ ~ Control / Mechanics ~ }

System Shock's approach to selecting and throwing certain items like grenades is unique but functional. After a bit of practice it gets easier but you need to be careful or else you'll blow yourself up.

The Classic version of System Shock is harder to play due to the outdated control mechanics, but the Enhanced version makes the game very playable almost like a real FPS. Playing the Enhanced version on PC really improves the feel of the game and makes moving through the environment and aiming more natural.

Sometimes games should be played because they are timeless experiences; sometimes games are the infancy of greatness for future games with unforeseen potential and consequences to create new genres; sometimes, however, games can only truly be appreciated as artifacts that you can play for yourself to relive the history they created after experiencing what wonders they inspired for the future. The original System Shock feels like this last category, and the only way I could recommend it is if you are an enthusiast who enjoys the idea of immersive sims and want to play something mechanically outdated to modern games for the sake of it.

In what is perhaps a more confusing situation than the default control scheme, the original System Shock: Enhanced Edition occupies a weird limbo state of remakes. System Shock 2, a game that clearly was a do-over of the original utilizing the same ideas with better polish and execution, was the remake from the past. System Shock (2018) is a modern reinterpretation of the original that will be a remake for the future. The Enhanced Edition is a modern computer friendly marvel that keeps everything about the original with more accessible controls with no changes made to the core game.  

Past, present or future, the legacy of System Shock is a series that encompasses its creators’ successors and other developer interpretations that all started with a hacker in space clutching a wrench against the horrors of the cybernetics and the future of technology awaiting him.

[h1]We All Live in a FPS-Submarine[/h1]

If anything about the original System Shock has proceeded its legacy it’s the infamous control scheme that will baffle anyone who grew up on modern games. Creating a control-scheme is a bygone problem as the adoption of controllers and expected control set-ups have standardized games, some may say for the worse, that have trained players to expect a certain set-up across all games. In many cases, an FPS will play much like any other one except for deviations of speed, emphasis on hip firing and/or iron-sights, and weapons that make up the arsenal of a game. Having to relearn a new control set-up for an establish genre is not something most players are going to accept, and it has forever been a black mark on the namesake of System Shock.

The way the controls are designed is they’re a hybrid of point-and-click and FPS set-ups that share functionality with one another to make up for the missing components players would expect in one genre or another. By default, players move as well as aim with the mouse by moving the cursor across the screen and clicking in the direction as well as to turn the camera by the edges of the screen; the keyboard changes the position of players to crouch, to lean left or right, and to hug the floor with their face. Menus open from tabs alongside the viewport that looks like a submarine periscope, which opens the interface to access audio logs, emails, items, ammo and reloading screens, etc. These considerations are on top of the maze-like areas that uses realistic living quarters, which can be aided by a vector map hidden inside one tab that shows more of the layout the further the player explores each floor of the Citadel. Along with the constant threats at every corner and the vague minigames to breach the station’s security, having to worry about the controls is the beginning of a player’s concerns. 

The Enhanced Edition streamlines some of these systems by utilizing a Mouse-Look button along with enabling full-screen to make movement conform to WASD standards; however, the menu system remains intact to the experience, which makes it easier to understand the more the player becomes familiar with the controls. Toning down the difficulty options for puzzles, combat and other options is preferable for the first experience as learning the unique controls is the first challenge the player must overcome, and it’s the only barrier of entry that the game possesses that would dissuade players from enjoying what elements hold up to modern standards.

[h1]One Is the Loneliest Number That You’ll Ever Do, Insect[/h1]

If anything about this game has withstood the test of time across various games it is the narrative elements that are at work to enhance the atmosphere and immersion that comes with it being an immersive sim. Inspired by Ultimate Underworld, the exploration and player freedom to wander the various levels of a station to solve given problems at the player’s pace is the cornerstone of the experience in SS. Audio-logs, email reports, an omnipresent threat, SHODAN, onboard a station that insults you at every corner for your destruction in a soothingly unpleasant mismatch of voices spliced together on top of the general atmosphere of hostility from all present threats gives a sublime presentation of audio and visual quality that remains as hauntingly surreal today as it was back in ’94. 

When it comes to the narrative itself, the original System Shock remains a threadbare story that relies more on its presentation than its themes or an overall plotline to enhance the experience. Even compared to the sequel, the character of SHODAN feels somewhat shallow than the sequel as her motivations cannot be contrasted with another threat such as the Hive to question the positives and benefits of AI. This is unlike the sequel which puts the player as the mediator of two vile extremes of philosophies that challenge the player’s states as a cybernetic human; the player is simply a hacker given an opportunity to clear his name to cause more ruckuses afterwards.  Here we have an omnipresent threat at one extreme who we only get to have the perspective of it being the antagonist, and the lack of conflicting supporting characters to weigh on the matter or to offer insight other than the scattered audio-logs and emails makes the experience fairly limited compared to its sequel and spiritual successors. 

None of this is to discredit the benefits of an immersive experience presented around the immersion of loneliness; however, the faults are more present as the result of having played games that have taken the basis of System Shock and made improvements in favor of telling an immersive story. 

[h1]It Belongs in a Museum[/h1]

Storytelling isn’t the only limitation with the original System Shock as the gameplay itself was designed to accommodate its awkward controls by stripping away any semblance of AI for enemies as well as making enemies with projectiles into hit-scan enemies. Even when it comes to the original DOOM, enemies possess some modicum of AI behavior as well as relying on multiple types of attack such as melee, projectile base and hit-scan weapons. System Shock feels threadbare as the result of making encounters based on keeping away and peeking around corners, which feels natural to an experience to instill fear into the player at every corner yet makes the core gameplay simplistic.

These are the aspects of a game that can only appreciated for what it was worth at the time that future iterations of System Shock are going to resolve many of its core problems to many audiences. However, if nostalgia is what drives you to play System Shock then the game will offer you a reason to go back into the past for a short while, then leave things where they belong as memories.

There are so many things one can say about System Shock that it's difficult to know where to start. At its core it is a first person immersive simulation that combines RPG elements with a player inventory and some solid shooting / melee combat against a variety of terrifying enemies.
The thing is, it isn't JUST this. It's Looking Glass product. It's an immersive simulation. It has unpredictable and labyrinthine levels to explore, fascinating back-story that isn't thrown in your face every five minutes, and it encourages careful resource management in a dangerous, malignant environment that exists entirely to end you. You are one man against many horrors, and System Shock MAKES you adjust to its rules, to its design, to its systems and world. It is a textbook example of "deep design gameplay" that involves more than simple shooting, more than simple clicking. It will challenge your spacial perception, your hand-eye coordination and your decision making.
System Shock is an object lesson in everything that is great about gaming as a medium. Though its setup and scenario may not be the most original in gaming, it is applied to a deep, clever, immersive and frightening experience that you will never, ever forget.

33727145.review:
[h1]★★✰✰✰[/h1]
An interesting piece of gaming history that hasn't aged well neither visually nor mechanically, even in areas where it originally excelled. You will find very little that isn't already done much better in more modern games, unless you're craving for some old-school jankiness.

Enhanced Edition runs well out of the box, adds mouselook, and supports custom and widescreen resolutions via a simple tweak to a config file.

. . . . . . . . . . .

Games like DOOM 1 & 2 stand strong to this day because their biggest strength is simple fast-paced dumb action - an old but proven formula for success.
System Shock instead took the path of slow-paced survival horror - a genre that was much more demanding, complex, and unexplored, and unfortunately it shows. 

System Shock has many elements you've probably seen in more modern games - inventory management, loot, upgrades, puzzles, text and audio logs, running around a space station fixing things while characters talk to you on the radio, all that stuff... except a lot more ugly and clunky. The environments are almost Minecraft-esque and consist of uniformly-spaced blocks, slabs and slopes, with only a handful of textures per level and some props. Non-stop upbeat music and almost complete lack of eerie ambience fail to maintain a scary atmosphere. If you're hoping for at least some decent shooter action - expect infuriatingly bad hit detection, clunky UI and floaty-bumpy movement physics. 

With neither the action nor atmosphere being very good - all you're left with is a cliche story and some puzzles, if you can stomach everything else.

So let me prefix this by saying, I have no nostalgia for this game; I didn't play it when it was new.  I did play System Shock 2, which is basically a generation or two ahead of this game.

That being said, this is legitimately one of the best games ever made and has some features I wish modern games had.

So, it took me maybe 3 times total to sit down and actually figure out how to play this game; the initial frustration and urge to quit is high, because this game comes from an era before modern control schemes.  This game can't decide if it wants to be a first-person shooter or a point-and-click adventure, and you have to toggle back and forth between both.

HOW TO PLAY
Let me save you some figuring it out; 'e' switches mode from mouse-look to point-and-click mode.  R/F/V are Stand/Crouch/Prone respectively, and z-x-c are lean left, center, and lean right.  My biggest frustration was I got stuck leaning right and couldn't figure out how to unstick it; the trick is to press 'x'.

Stay in FPS mode for most of the game, use 'e' to switch to point and click mode when you absolutely have to (mostly for looting).  This should be enough to get you past the first room :)

Right click shoots, left click looks, and double-click activates.  Another oddity compared to modern games!

NOW, WHY IS IT GOOD
So, first off, forgive the horrid voice acting -- most people in the game were clearly the developers themselves lending voice and face to characters.  This game was from a different era, so prepare for some really bad voice acting.  That aside, it's a beautifully (for the time) rendered environment, with lots of detail, and its overall quite well written and produced.

There's a lot to do, and if you just want to be a tourist, you can tune the game to your taste.  For my playthrough, I turned off enemies; or rather, set their difficulty to 0 so they wouldn't attack.  You can also turn off the obnoxious puzzles in the game, which I highly recommend.  Doing that, you can tour around and enjoy the story.  The clunky interface is a lot less bothersome when you're not trying to fight.

I wish more games would be tunable in this way; so many times I've picked up a game and got wore out of the repetitive combat and wished I could just turn it off.

So if you find the game frustrating, try that.  Then explore -- there's a lot to see and find, and it's certainly a piece of game history.

32826386.review:
How do you review an old game? Do you judge them against the standards of the time as well as their historical importance? Or do you just damn the torpedoes and judge them by modern standards, pixilated warts and all? Sometimes it actually makes surprisingly little difference – Super Metroid for example is as playable and captivating as it was back in 1994.

System Shock also came out in 1994, and time has not been kind. It was released right in the middle of that uncomfortable, awkward puberty that was early 3D videogames (and is dressed in the gaming equivalent of a Marilyn Manson t-shirt and leather trousers). System Shock was obviously in development before Doom was released – nearly everything looked embarrassingly dated when that hit the shelves, and this game was no exception.

System Shock by modern standards is clunky almost to the point of unplayability – it should say something that the biggest addition to the “enhanced” edition is the ability to mouselook rather than slowly and painfully pan with the direction keys, though even this is set on an awkward toggle. The labyrinthine menus are baffling, the movement is slow and cumbersome and the combat is so god awful and the AI so braindead that exploiting it is standard procedure.

But there’s such a wealth of ambition, imagination and creativity here that I can’t bring myself to lay the boot in. System Shock was pretty much treading entirely new ground, and while the execution is often not great there was essentially no blueprint to follow outside of the Ultima games (which it resembles far more closely than the likes of Doom). The level design and atmosphere still hold up, and a surprisingly excellent automap stops you getting lost in the wonderfully intricate, sprawling environments.

In some ways the biggest sin this game commits is that it has too many ideas – no idea is left behind, no matter how half baked and over ambitious. There’s a massively confusing 3D wireframe hacking game that plays like a crap version of Descent. The cybernetic upgrades are mostly completely worthless, and there’s a poorly implemented energy system to power them all. Reloading a gun is a 12 step procedure that requires 2 keys and authorisation from NORAD.

Really, the biggest triumph of System Shock is that it laid the groundwork for its more fondly remembered sequel – a game that although a little wonky is an absolute classic, and is still very playable even today. As a piece of gaming history the original System Shock is fascinating, but I’m not sure I can recommend actually playing it to any but the most patient and dedicated.

32587315.review:
I am a huge fan of System Shock 2 and consider it to be one of my personal favourite games ever. So you can imagine my delight when I was finally able to get my hands on and play the original System Shock here on steam. And whilst I still think SS2 is a much better game, I sincerely enjoyed playing this.
System Shock is an oldschool FPS in which you play as a hacker who must stop a rogue AI who has taken over the Citadel space station from taking over/destroying the Earth. Seems straightforward enough, but what I really like about the story is how it always feels like it’s moving forward. You wake up and find everything’s gone to hell. You desperately try and figure out what’s going on and how to stop it. And every time it seems like you've foiled SHODAN's plans, she’s still one step ahead of you, so it's up to you to keep up and try and save the Earth. I really like this as it seriously draws you in. You want to keep playing to find out what happens next and to get the last laugh in. Even though the graphics and controls haven't aged well, I find System Shock to be a deeply immersive game.

In saying that, it is true that the controls are what really holds the game back. I am very grateful for the enhanced edition because it fixes the most glaring issues (lack of mouselook and low res words). Seriously, not having mouselook really held the game back in my opinion. I've heard some people say that the lack of mouselook helps add in a layer of helplessness that contributes to the horror atmosphere and to an extent they're right. But there's a fine line between feeling powerless against overwhelming odds and just feeling frustrated with stilted controls and this being more of a shooter than a horror game, I find myself drifting towards the latter. To be honest, the controls aren't too terrible. I really like the controllable and interruptible lean as it can really help in being able to out manoeuvre and snipe enemies. 

My biggest gripe with the game though is its frankly atrocious UI. Unlike in SS2 where you just pressed tab and your inventory/stats screen showed up instantly, SS1's UI is broken up into several small tabs lined along the bottom/side of the screen that you have to manually click on to open. And navigating them is a right chore, ESPECIALLY when you're in the middle of an intense moment and you need to heal or reload your weapon. You need to exit mouselook, click on the appropriate tab and double click on the appropriate item to use and then go back into mouselook. This is awfully time consuming and needlessly complex. 

On that note, a lack of hotkeys is also another big problem with the game. Instead of having each weapon mapped to a button, you toggle through them with the "q" key. This is annoying enough as getting to the weapon you want is annoying enough if you accidently go past it as you're frantically cycling though your weapon, but this is further compounded by the fact that there is no reload button. You have to bring up your weapons menu to select your weapon and bring up the weapon sub menu to be able to reload your weapon and then click on the ammo icon to reload your weapon. This is especially galling if you get in a fight and need to reload you weapon. Either you quickly toggle through to another one to finish the enemy off or you run and hide to buy enough time to bring up the menu to manually reload. I suppose this can be argued to be in the games favour as it adds to the horror atmosphere by adding a touch of realism because y'know, in a real gunfight you can't just instantly reload. And not gonna lie, that is the case sometimes because it adds a layer of desperation to survive if you're getting low on health and haven't been able to activate a restoration bay. But then again, it also can cause some cheap deaths, which no one is a fan of. 

The cyberspace minigames are also something I'm not a fan of as they're incredibly esoteric in design and are just sorta there. You just sorta float around in cyberspace, avoid enemies and collect packets of data and such. Not helped are the awkward and floaty controls and unintuitive display. 

And finally, the level design leaves a lot to be desired. To an extent, it's a pretty good layout having multiple elevators connected to a series of floors connected to a vertical shaft. But the low res graphics combined with some truly maze-like levels lead to me getting lost multiple times despite the fact I have played this game several times. The engineering level is probably the worst offender being both a massive level and having several areas look the same, leading to me getting lost and not knowing which way to go and where I've already been.

At this point, it may seem like I'm down on the game because I've been slagging it off for the last few paragraphs. And while it's true that in retrospect the game wasn't as good as I was expecting, the true value of SS1 comes from the experience. It's a lot like Dark Souls in the fact that taken at face values by the value of its mechanics alone, it's not that remarkable. But it's all about the adventure and the experience. SS1 is greater than the sum of its parts. It's incredibly immersive and once you get into the groove of things, it quickly becomes addictive and hard to put down. The issues I talked about at length before aren't deal breakers and can be easily worked around (but are issues none the less) and gotten used to.

The story is probably the best part of SS1. I quite like how it's all up to you to figure out from the audio logs and emails to figure out what to do and where to go. SS1 respects your intelligence and trusts that you'll be able to use the pieces of information you're given and that you find to piece together your objective. And that makes it all the more satisfying to work through the game. You feel as though it was you besting SHODAN and not the game telling you how. Admittedly I was more down on this aspect when I first started playing because I easily got lost on what I had to do and what I had already done. But in retrospect, this was a nice touch of realism. No ones going to tell you what you need to do and what you've already done. It's up to you.

And really, it's just so much fun working your way through Citadel station, getting better weapons and upgrades, being able to traverse areas you previously couldn't and piecing together what happened from the audiologs scattered here and there. 29733588.review:
System Shock is an incredibly interesting game when playing it in a modern context. In early first person shooters, such as Doom, you would mow down enemies for the fun of it in sets of various mazes. In later games of the same genre, like Half-Life, you would fight to progress through a well-defined story. System Shock however has you do both of these things, and in doing so shows how shooters evolved. Each level of the game is absolutely a maze, complete with the traditional elevators, which you must navigate and kill hordes of enemies to get through. But there is also a dense and well written narrative, with voice acting, to constantly motivate you onwards.

While progressing through the game you can see the rugged incarnations of the many narrative and gameplay mechanics which have become mainstays to the medium. Early forms of storytelling systems like cutscenes and audio logs play out through the game's email system. Early roleplaying systems like attribute-specific stat boosters and enemy-type only effective weapons are incorporated into the basic gunplay. Backtracking to previous levels to reach previously unavailable areas with the help of new gear, a la Metroid, even gives the game an open-ended feel.

There are many aspects of System Shock, like the controls, that show their age. But other parts remain remarkably fresh. The art design of Citadel Station and the world building applied to it are impressive to this. Each level of the station feels like an almost entirely different location with its own purpose and the environment as a whole actually feels alive. The various characters which pop up in the audio and written recordings even feel rooted and meaningful to the setting. While you never meet another person the entire game, Citadel Station feels alive. Add to this the inclusion of a great, if repetitive, soundtrack and you'll be delighted to take your time exploring all the station's dark corners.

The game's dated design does mean it will take some time getting comfortable with the controls. But once you settle into the handling of your character and get a sense of exactly how you will progress, it's difficult to put the mouse down. And thanks to one of gaming's most iconic antagonists, you're sure to be satisfied once the final shot has been fired. System Shock may have not aged perfectly, but it’s still a great game that's worth your time.
